Multi-center validation and evaluation of strategies for rule incorporation are warranted.598 Systemic Antibiotics after Incision and Drainage of Simple Abscesses: A Meta-Analysis Adam J. Singer, and Henry C. Thode Jr Stony Brook University, Stony Brook, NY Background: Over the last decade there has been a significant increase in the number of cutaneous abscesses. While there is general agreement that abscesses should be treated with incision and drainage, it is unclear whether systemic antibiotics should be routinely prescribed. Objectives: To evaluate whether systemic antibiotics, when compared with a placebo, improve resolution rates in patients with simple abscesses after incision and drainage. Methods: Design: Systematic review and meta-analysis using RevMan5. Patients and settings: Children and adults with simple abscesses treated in outpatient clinics or emergency departments. Data sources: Cochrane Central, Medline, Embase, and bibliographies. Outcome measures: Percentage of patients with complete resolution of abscess without the need for recurrent incision and drainage, additional antibiotics, or hospital admission within 7-10 days of treatment. Results: We included four trials, consisting of 589 patients in total (428 adults and 161 children). Patients were randomized to one of three antibiotics (cephridine [27], cephalexin [82], or trimethoprim sulfamethoxazole [161]) or to placebo (285) with 34 lost to follow-up or having incomplete data. When given in addition to incision and drainage, systemic antibiotics did not significantly improve the percentage of patients with complete resolution of their abscesses 7-10 days after treatment (88.1% vs. 86.0%; odds ratio 1.17, 95% CI, 0.70 to 1.95).Conclusion: When given in addition to incision and drainage, systemic antibiotics do not significantly improve the percentage of patients with complete resolution of their abscesses.

TABREF58.text: Abstract 121: Predictors of adverse 30 day return visit (n=34) SLG). All were required to see 10 specific chief complaints and were loaned a standard EM textbook. The SLG was instructed to read about the required cases in the textbook. The DLG attended a 2-hour didactic session covering five of the required case presentations, chosen to be a diverse representation of EM pathology. All students completed an identical pre-and post-clerkship multiple choice knowledge test consisting of 15 items created by clerkship instructors. Data were evaluated with analysis of variance.Results: Fifty-one students participated (DLG = 27; SLG = 24). MeanFigure -Abstract 123: Knowledge in the Dual Learning Group vs Standard Learning GroupResults: The assessment was scored for 38 EM residents and 35 EM attendings. A variety of ages, training levels, and genders were represented. The residents, regardless of training program, age, or gender, shared the accommodating learning style. The attending analysis showed that attendings aged <40 shared the accommodating learning style and attendings aged >40 shared the diverging learning style. Accommodating learners excel at putting ideas into action, adapt well to changing circumstances, are intuitive, and use trial and error to obtain answers. Divergent learners are imaginative, consider many perspectives, and seek abundant information before making decisions.Conclusion: Historically, learning styles have been used as a framework for curriculum design and to influence educators but it has not been studied in EM. At the institution where this study was conducted, the majority of residents and faculty shared the accommodating learning style. This may have implications for curriculum redesign that will result in more effective educational experiences for residents.Conclusion: The Ottawa M&M model is an effective educational intervention which we believe could be readily applied to any hospital department seeking to enhance quality of care and patient safety.

TABREF63.text: Objectives: Our objective was to determine if the NEXUS criteria would still be sensitive in blunt trauma patients suffering a femur fracture without the fracture being considered a "distracting injury" and an absolute indication for diagnostic imaging.Background: Spine fractures are common in trauma patients. Non-Conclusion: According to our data, of those trauma patients with spine fractures, approximately one in five will have non-contiguous fractures. Non-contiguous spine fractures and delays of diagnosis are associated with a higher mortality rate.Background: In blunt trauma patients, chest CT (CCT) helps identify otherwise missed injuries. However, many injuries identified only by CTT require no additional intervention. The diagnostic value of CCT is questionable in the context of increasing concerns about radiation exposure and its potential cancer risk. Identifying clinical findings that predict which patients are unlikely to require surgical intervention based on CCT findings might limit the number of unnecessary CT scans.Objectives: Determine whether five readily available clinical findings can predict which patients will not require a surgical intervention due to CCT findings.Methods: Using the registry at our Level I trauma center, we conducted a retrospective chart review of blunt trauma patients admitted in 2009 who underwent CCTs during their initial evaluations. Exclusion criteria were GCS of <15, no CXR performed, or transfer from another ED. The five clinical findings examined were sBP <90 mmHg, SaO2 <95%, chest pain, shortness of breath, and presence of an abnormal CXR. Other data collected included CCT findings and interventions after CCT including chest tube or other thoracic surgery. Univariate and multivariate logistic regression analyses were performed to identify variables significantly associated with the need for intervention.

TABREF66.text: : Late breaking data available in February.Objectives: We sought to identify the PPV of a PNA triage tool and hypothesized it would be as high as other reported PPV with similar triage criteria.Methods:We performed a retrospective observational study at an urban academic ED of a triage pathway that had been initiated in 2006 to aid in conforming to CMS PNA core measures. We reviewed data from Feb 2010 to Mar 2012. Patients were triaged to the pathway if they were older than 18 years old and had two or more of the following: fever more than 38°C, cough, shortness of breath, pleuritic chest pain, pulse oximetry less than 94%, altered breath sounds, or pulse more than 90/min. Exclusion criteria in the study were subjects who left without being seen, prisoners, and pregnant woman. If placed on the pathway, a CXR was ordered by the triage RN and a physician reviewed the CXR when completed. Our primary outcome was PPV of the triage tool to identify PNA. PNA was defined as the clinical diagnosis made by the treating ED physician.

TABREF67.text: Objectives: To determine the accuracy of the physiologic criteria(Step 1) of the Field Triage Guidelines in identifying severely injured children.Methods: EMS providers who transported injured children 15years to pediatric trauma centers in three mid-sized cities were interviewed regarding patient demographics and the Guidelines for Field Triage criteria. Children were considered to have needed a trauma center if they had non-orthopedic surgery within 24 hours, ICU admission, or died. The over-and under-triage rates and positive likelihood ratios (+LR) were calculated for the overall physiologic criteria and each individual criterion.Conclusion:The physiologic criteria are a moderate predictor of trauma center need for children. Missing or inaccurate vital signs may be limiting the predictive value of the physiologic criteria.

TABREF68.text: Conclusion: Resident facilitated procedural sedation is safe and efficacious. Complication rates were similar to prior studies evaluating procedural sedations performed by ED physicians. We found that use of ETCO2 monitoring allowed early initiation of simple airway interventions prior to oxygen desaturation.Background: Pain is the most common chief complaint for patients seeking care in the emergency department (ED). Up to 70% of ED visits are related to pain as the reason for the ED visit. Opioids are commonly used to treat pain but have undesirable side effects: nausea, vomiting, hypotension, respiratory depression, and the potential for addiction. Ketorolac, an effective pain reliever, is nonaddicting and avoids the side effects of opioids. The oral route of drug administration may not be feasible in some patients (e.g. vomiting, ileus) while other routes of dispensing medications (IV or IM) can be painful. The intranasal (IN) route eliminates the pain of a needlestick. IN ketorolac has not been evaluated for the treatment of pain in a prospective trial in ED patients.Objectives: To determine if IN ketorolac is safe, effective, and welltolerated in treating ED patients with painful conditions. Conclusion: Intranasal ketorolac effectively decreases pain in adult patients in the ED for a wide variety of chief complaints and many different types of pain. Moreove, it is safe and well-tolerated .ED Pain Care and its Effects on Short Term Hospitalization OutcomesAmmar Siddiqui, and Ula Y. Hwang Mount Sinai School of Medicine, New York, NY Background: Hospitalized patients often arrive through the ED, where pain care may be initiated for their conditions. Unrelieved acute pain increases the risk of chronic pain and delirium. Little is known, however, whether ED pain care affects hospitalization outcomes. >4 point reduction in ED pain scores (initial -final pain score) was correlated with lower opioid dose on HD1 (-10.7, p=0.02) and lower number of HD1 analgesics (0.78, p=0.05). Time to pain relief in the ED, age, sex, comorbidity, race, and the number of prior medications were not associated with hospital analgesic use.Objectives: We compared the VITA to the NRS in the ED setting to evaluate accuracy and ease of use.

TABREF69.text: : 199 ED patients agreed to participate in the study. 95% of patients found the VITA scale easy to use and reported favorable accuracy of the VITA. 67% of patients preferred the VITA to the NRS. When evaluating the NRS, we noted significant variation in scores by education level, race, and sex, but these differences were not present in VITA scores. Similarly, odds of receiving opioid medication varied significantly as a function of level of education with NRS scores Conclusion: As a preliminary study of a novel tool for the measurement of pain in the ED, our results suggest improved accuracy and ease of use of the VITA scale compared to the traditional NRS. Additional research may further illuminate the advantages of this approach to pain assessment, as well as the clinical significance of potential effects on the treatment of pain in the ED.Background: The recent NAP4 study reported a larger number of complications from the ICU than the ED and OR during emergency airway management. 61% of the reported complications suffered death or brain damage, illustrating the importance of optimizing airway management in the ICU setting. The optimal device for intubation in the ICU remains unknown.Conclusion: Video laryngoscopy is associated with a decreased the first attempt esophageal intubation rate and increased first attempt success rates compared to direct laryngoscopy.Objectives: 1. To better appreciate the proportion of all angioedema that is ACE-I induced. 2. To describe the medical management of AAE in two Canadian tertiary care EDs. 3. To identify any epinephrine induced morbidity.Conclusion: Our study demonstrates that AAE is the most common identifiable etiology of angioedema. Management of AAE commonly includes antihistamines and corticosteroids. Concerningly, epinephrine use is common. Many patients are started on an ACE-I for cardioprotection post-myocardial infarct. There is little physiologic rationale for epinephrine use in AAE and much risk. More work is necessary to better delineate epinephrine's role in this vulnerable patient population.

TABREF71.text: Conclusion:Our experience with novice HO shows infant VL in normal airways is a quickly acquired skill in physicians of all backgrounds including EM. Similar to adult data it appears the learning curve of infant laryngoscopy flattens after three attempts. The AAP Neonatal Resuscitation Program guidelines recommend a 20s limit to intubate. Our data show HO coached through videolaryngoscopy are able to intubate in 20s in an airway mannequin. Further study should be done to evaluate the longevity of skills after a single session and the translation of airway skills learned in simulation to the clinical setting.

Evaluation for the increase in troponin and CKMB over 12 hours has become the standard for ruling in ACS; yet at times discordant CKMB and troponin values occur. Thus, the value of trending CKMB in this setting comes into questionObjectives: We hypothesized that, in CEU patients, regardless of the CKMB trend, if there was not an elevation in troponin there would not be a significant cardiac finding associated with ACS. Outcome was defined as positive confirmatory test for cardiac pathology. Testing methods included nuclear stress test, exercise stress test, coronary artery CT angiogram, or stress echo. Sex, cocaine use, and cardiac enzyme (CK, CKMB, and troponin) results were also recorded. Fisher's exact test was used to detect differences between those with and without disease who had positive cardiac markers.Conclusion: There may be limited value to trending CKMB to rule in ACS in the setting of emergency department based chest pain observation units.

TABREF87.text: Abstract 169: Hypertension Knowledge of Inner City ED and Midwestern Primary Care Patients Table -Abstract 170: Testing Threshold at Extremes of Two-way Sensitivity Analysis for Major and Minor Drivers The methodological quality of the studies was assessed. Results Our initial search found 219 articles through PubMed and 390 by EMBASE, three prospective studies (n = 93 patients) and two retrospective studies (n = 166 patients) met our inclusion/exclusion criteria. Methodological quality of all reviewed studies was rated as unclear or high risk of bias for randomization and concealment and low risk of bias for blinding. The three prospective studies compared VT termination between lidocaine versus procainamide, amjaline, and sotalol. The two retrospective trials tested lidocaine against procainamide, amjaline, sotalol, and amiodarone.Conclusion: For the treatment of stable, monomorphic ventricular tachycardia, the antiarrhythmics procainamide, amjaline, and sotalol were all superior to lidocaine.Objectives: We sought to describe the utilization of our EDOU for young patients with chest pain and evaluate the utility of this approach for risk stratification in this patient population.Methods: This prospective, cohort study of severely hypertensive patients (SBP ! 180 or DBP ! 120 mm Hg at triage or on reassessment) was conducted in an academic ED over 3 months in 2012. Patients were eligible if ! 18 years old, were not pregnant, and provided informed consent. Research associates performed BP reassessments immediately after the initial physician contact, prior to medication administration, and also collected demographic data and presenting symptoms. Medical evaluation, management, and final disposition were ascertained via medical record review. Data are presented as means (SD) and proportions. Multivariable logistic regression identified factors associated with hospital admission.Conclusion: Even in patients with BP elevations consistent with hypertensive crisis, ancillary testing is not comprehensive and admission for further management does not appear to be associated with abnormal testing results, symptoms or insurance status.

TABREF88.text: Background: Out-of-hospital cardiac arrest (OHCA) characteristics differ by sex, with females less likely to have a witnessed arrest or a shockable rhythm. Nonetheless, shockable rhythms and application of automated external defibrillators (AEDs) remain a critical component of the chain of survival. To date, there is a paucity of research that evaluates sex disparities and AED application in OHCA. We hypothesized that female sex would be negatively associated with AED application following OHCA.Methods:We conducted a secondary analysis of prospectively collected data from the Cardiac Arrest Registry to Enhance Survival (CARES), which includes data from 29 cities in the United States. Patients were included if they were ! 18 years of age, had nontraumatic, non-EMS witnessed OHCA, and had a documented resuscitation attempt from October 1, 2005 through December 31, 2011. Bivariate differences were calculated and hierarchical multivariable logistic regression analysis was used to estimate associations between sex and AED application as the primary outcome.Conclusion: In a national sample of adult OHCA patients, female sex was negatively associated with AED application when adjusted for multiple confounders. Additional research is needed to identify ways to eliminate this disparity in order to improve survival from OHCATable: Abstract 174 175 A Prospective Trial of Video Podcast Use to Improve Knowledge and Confidence in Violent Person Management within an Emergency Medicine Clerkship Caroline A. Ball, Alicia M. Kurtz, and Trent Reed Loyola University Chicago, Maywood, IL Background: The Joint Commission issued Sentinel Event Alert #45in June 2010 highlighting the significant problem of violence in the health care setting. Several studies have demonstrated that quality staff training programs improve attitudes, confidence, knowledge, and skills pertaining to violent person management (VPM). Separately, it has been shown that web-based video lectures are a useful tool for presenting information to medical students on clinical rotations. Combining this information, we examined the effect of a video podcast on medical student knowledge and comfort in dealing with VPM in the emergency department (ED).

Pediatric residents infrequently perform this role and data on their performance is lacking.Objectives: To summarize primary and secondary survey performance in pediatric trauma resuscitation and determine association between provider characteristics and survey quality.Conclusion: Primary and secondary surveys are frequently performed incompletely regardless of level of training or type of training program. There is no difference in measured performance among different programs. The effect of trauma resuscitation education on improved survey performance should be studied prospectively.The millennial generation's interest in easily accessible education materials is forcing educators to reevaluate how they teach. EMRAP's Mel Herbert recently tweeted "Traditional texts are dead." This sentiment appears to be pervasive amongst our youngest and most influential learners and educators.Objectives: To determine emergency medicine residents' current methods and preferences of obtaining medical knowledge.Conclusion: Medical education must reevaluate the way in which we teach residents and expect them to learn. Our survey confirms that the trend is moving away from traditional means such as books and journals and utilizing more open access interactive multimedia tools. Our role as medical educations must also shift to engage with our current learners, to guide appropriate use and to strengthen our own education methods.Background: Evaluation of medical student performance in an EM clerkship requires an assessment of clinical performance by faculty most often using an end-of-shift evaluation form. TABREF196.text: Objectives: To assess, at 3-days post-ED discharge, patients' comprehension of their ED care and post-care instructions. To explore patient factors associated with poor comprehension.Methods: A convenience sample of ED patients aged 65 years and older were approached between June and August, 2012 at one of two academic EDs in Western Pennsylvannia, and excluded if they lived in a nursing home or assisted living center, were critically ill, or could not follow basic commands. Participants completed the Short Blessed Test (SBT: cognitive impairment), the Geriatric Depression Screen (GDS), and Snellen vision chart testing. Structured telephone interviews were conducted within 72 hours of discharge from the ED and assessed four domains of comprehension: diagnosis, expected course of illness, selfcare instructions, and return precautions. We performed univatate logistic regressions to determine the strength of association of various factors with poor comprehension.Conclusion: Many older community dwelling patients do not understand their care or their discharge instructions. Strategies incorporating dementia screens are needed to improve identification of older patients at higher risk for poor comprehension.

Impact of a New Senior Emergency Screening and Social Work Intervention on Patient Satisfaction as Measured by Press Ganey Survey Methodology Daniel Keyes 1 , Nic Branscomb 2 , Andrew Gough 3 , Belinda Dokic 3 , and Michael Calice 3 Univ of Michigan EM Residency Program, Ann Arbor, MI; 2 St Joseph Mercy Health System, Livonia, MI; 3 St Mary Mercy Hospital, Livonia, MI Background: Studies are needed to describe the new senior

TABREF198.text: top decile of patient satisfaction. Future research should focus on important outcomes for this new type of specialized ED.Background: Packed red blood cell (pRBC) transfusion is common in resuscitating critically ill patients. However, the effectiveness of the pRBC transfusion in patients with severe sepsis remains controversial.Objectives: We aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of pRBC transfusion in severe sepsis patients visiting the emergency department (ED).Methods:We conducted an observational study consisting of all nontraumatic adult patients visiting the ED of a tertiary hospital during the year 2010 with suspected sepsis and two sets of blood cultures ordered by emergency physicians. Basic demographics, ED vital signs, symptoms and signs, underlying illnesses, laboratory findings, microbiological results and discharge status were collected. Severe sepsis was defined as sepsis with organ dysfunction. Chi-square test and two-sample t-test were utilized to analyze the different characteristics between patients with and without pRBC transfusion. The propensity score (PS) matchingbased method was subsequently used to eliminate the potential confounding. We then compared the mortality rate between the two groups with multivariate logistic regression model utilized to adjust theFigure -Abstract 308 potential residual confounding. The effectiveness of pRBC transfusion among patients with different hemoglobin levels was further evaluated.Results: Of the 3020 patients included, 91 patients underwent pRBC infusion. Patients who had pRBC infusion tended to have lower mean arterial pressure (86 vs. 97 mmHg) and hemoglobin level (7.5 v.s 11.3 mg/dL) (all p<0.05) . Overall, there were 25 deaths in transfused group vs. 315 deaths in the non-transfused group (27.4% vs. 10.7%, P<0.001). However, after the PS matching, the two groups were nearly comparable except hemoglobin level (7.5 vs. 8 mg/dL, p = 0.03) with similar mortality rate (27 vs. 23 %; P =0.48) after adjusting for hemoglobin level. Furthermore, we found no significant interaction between pRBC infusion and hemoglobin level.

TABREF199.text: : Of 484 patients with septic shock presenting to the ED, 290 patients were included. The mean age was 63AE13 years and 60.2% were male. The 30-day mortality rate was 19.2%. The BNP levels and SOFA score were significantly higher in non-survival group compared with survival group (469.1 vs. 1155.9 pg/mL, p<0.01; 7.8 vs. 10.0, p<0.01, respectively). In the ROC curves for predicting 28-day mortality, the area under the curves of SOFA score combined with BNP was 0.714 (95% CI 0.658-0.765, P<0.01) and for SOFA score alone was 0.682 (95% CI 0.626-0.736, P<0.01). The predictive ability of SOFA score combined with BNP was significantly improved than that of SOFA score alone (P=0.04).Conclusion: The combination of SOFA score with BNP level may provide superior prognostic accuracy to SOFA score alone in patients with septic shock at ED. TABREF201.text: Abstract 311Background: Murine models of septic shock using cecal ligation and perforation have well-developed criteria for prediciting severity based upon parameters such as number of perforations of the cecum. Swine models are not as well characterized.Objectives: We sought to refine a technique for rapid development of septic shock in several hours, with measurable changes in HR, MAP, SVR, and SvO2.

TABREF202.text: : All animals developed septic shock. Mean times (and , TEMP +0.58 C, CO -4.2 L/min, SvO2 -28.8%. Two animals required bolus doses of epinephrine in additional to vasopressor drip because of continuously declining MAP, two required chest compressions for approximately one minute each, and one required cardioversion for tachydysrhythmia. All animals survived until the end of the experiment.Conclusion:We demonstrate standardized cecal ligation and perforation plus fecal inoculation results in rapid development of septic shock, and that animals remain critically ill but survived to the end of the experiment.Background: Emergency department (ED) sepsis care focuses on reducing short-term in-hospital mortality, with little attention given to longer-term outcomes.Objectives: We sought to characterize long-term mortality after ED or hospital presentation with sepsis.Methods:We conducted a population-based longitudinal study using the 30,239 person REasons for Geographic and Racial Differences in Stroke (REGARDS) cohort. Using structured medical record review, we identified ED or initial hospital treatment for sepsis, defined as a serious infection with ! 2 systemic inflammatory response syndrome criteria). We identified all-cause mortality over an 8-year follow-up period after the sepsis event. Using Cox regression with sepsis defined as a time-varying covariate, we compared the relative risks of death between sepsis and non-sepsis individuals over time, adjusting for age, sex, race, education, income, geographic region, tobacco and alcohol use, and chronic medical conditions. Conclusion: While the risk of sepsis in-hospital mortality is well known, in this study high rates of death persisted for four years after sepsis hospitalization. Sepsis entails long-term health after-effects that extend beyond its initial ED and in-hospital care.Risk Factors for Infection with Resistant Organisms in Severe Sepsis Patients Admitted from the Emergency Department David F. Gaieski 1 , Munish Goyal 2 , Anish K. Agarwal 1 , Byron Drumheller 1 , Sarah Sante 1 , Mark Weiner 1 , Jason Christie 1 , Mark Mikkelsen 1 , and Andrew Shorr 3 The University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA; 2 Georgetown University, Washington D.C., DC; 3 Washington Hospital Center, Washington D.C., DC Background: Severe sepsis is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality, with US mortality exceeding 20% and the number of cases increasing annually. Optimal management includes early identification, resuscitation at the most proximal phase of critical illness, and timely administration of appropriate antimicrobials. Therapy has been complicated by the emergence of resistant organisms. Objectives: We hypothesized nursing home residents (NH) as well as elderly, immunocompromised, neutropenic, and end-stage renal disease (ESRD) patients would have increased prevalence of resistant organisms and that presence of resistant organisms would be associated with increased hospital length of stay (LOS) and mortality. Methods: A retrospective chart review was conducted of severe sepsis patients admitted to an urban, level I trauma center from the emergency department (ED) between May 2008 and February 2010. Data abstraction was completed by a trained researcher using a standardized form. Severe sepsis was defined as the presence of ! 2 SIRS criteria; a confirmed or suspected source of infection; and the presence of ! 1 acute organ dysfunction. Cases of resistant organism infection were identified as positive culture revealing MRSA, VRE, pseudomonas aeruginosa, or ESBL klebsiella. Odds ratios were calculated for resistant infection, age (>65 years), NH resident, immunosuppression (chemotherapy or daily steroids), neutropenia, ESRD, and mortality. Student's t-test was used to analyze LOS. Results: 1,148 patients with severe sepsis were identified; 570 had culture-positive infection. Mean age was 58 years; 36% Caucasian; 44%African-American; in-hospital mortality was 11.6%. 26% had confirmed resistant organism infection. ESRD was found to be the most significant risk factor (OR 4.65), followed by immunosuppression (OR 1.43) and neutropenia (OR 1.45). Age >65, NH residence, mortality, and LOS were not correlated.

TABREF203.text: ). In both urban and rural hospitals, higher case volume of severe sepsis was associated with lower mortality. Rural hospitals with greater than 250 cases annually had substantially decreased mortality (OR 0.71, 95% CI 0.61-0.82) compared to rural centers with less than 50 cases annually. Similarly, patients with severe sepsis treated at urban hospitals with greater than 500 cases annually had a significant survival advantage compared to facilities with less than 50 cases annually (OR 0.70, 95% CI 0.65-0.76). Unadjusted mortality was lower in rural compared to urban hospitals (27.1% vs 30.0%). In an adjusted analysis, urban hospitals had improved overall survival (OR 0.82 , 95% CI0.79-0.86). In a subgroup analysis, urban hospitals had improved survival in patients who had Conclusion: Mortality from severe sepsis is lower in facilities with higher case volumes in both urban and rural locales. Systems factors such as prolonged transport times and decreased staffing in rural EDs and ICUs may play a significant role in the observed mortality difference between urban and rural facilities. Regionalized and integrated systems of care may improve outcomes at hospitals with higher risk of mortality in patients with severe sepsis.
