Ward, and David A. Pearson Carolinas Medical Center, Charlotte, NC Background: Therapeutic hypothermia (TH) improves patient survival with good neurologic outcome after cardiac arrest. To date, the value of early clinician prognostication in the ED has not been studied in this patient population.Objectives: To determine if physicians can accurately predict survival and neurologic outcome at hospital discharge of resuscitated, comatose out-of-hospital cardiac arrest (OHCA) patients treated in a post-arrest clinical pathway that included TH.

TABREF204.text: : Twenty-one patients were enrolled from October 2009 to March 2010 with four patients excluded due to TH termination, resulting in 42 physician completed questionnaires on the remaining 17 patients. There were no differences in demographics, initial rhythm, overall survival, or neurologic outcome of study patients as compared to our cardiac arrest registry (n=308, November 2007 to August 2012). Sensitivity and specificity of clinician prediction of patient survival was Conclusion: Although better at predicting survival as compared to good neurologic outcome, physicians poorly prognosticate both survival and neurologic outcome in comatose OHCA patients undergoing TH. Therefore, premature prognostication in the ED should be avoided.Background: Patients who suffer from post-cardiac arrest syndrome (PCAS) often exhibit an inflammatory response similar to a sepsis syndrome. Invasive hemodynamic monitoring of resuscitative endpoints has been proven to impart better mortality outcomes in sepsis and has been recommended for goal-directed management of PCAS patients.

TABREF205.text: Results: A total of 111 patients were enrolled. Patients were 61 AE 16.8 years, 59.5% male, 60.4% Caucasian, and had an initial rhythm of VF/VT in 50.5% of cases. At baseline, very few patients had CVP or ScvO2 measurements recorded (12 and 4, respectively). During the middle 24 hours, 72 patients (65%) had CVP recordings and 24 (21.6%) had ScvO2 recorded. ScvO2 values were not significant between patients with good versus poor neurologic outcome at all times. Lower CVP measurement was associated with better neurologic outcome.Conclusion: ScvO2 was infrequently utilized in this cohort of PCAS patients undergoing TH. CVP was utilized at higher rates, and lower CVP recordings were correlated with better neurologic outcome.

TABREF206.text: Abstract 317: CVP and Neurologic StatusBackground: Neuromuscular blockade may improve outcomes in patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome. In post-cardiac arrest patients receiving therapeutic hypothermia, neuromuscular blockade is often used to prevent shivering.

TABREF207.text: Results: A total of 111 patients were analyzed and 69% of patients received neuromuscular blockade at some point within 24 hours of return of spontaneous circulation (see table for patient characteristics). In patients with 24 hours of sustained neuromuscular blockade, the crude survival rate was 14/18 (78%), compared to 38/93 (41%) in patients without sustained neuromuscular blockade (p = 0.004). After multivariable adjustment, neuromuscular blockade was associated with survival (adjusted OR: 7.23, 95% CI: 1.56 -33.38). There was a trend toward improved neurological outcome with neuromuscular blockade (50% vs. 28%; p = 0.07). Sustained neuromuscular blockade was associated with improved lactate clearance (adjusted p = 0.01, seefigure).

TABREF208.text: Background: Specific hemodynamic optimization strategies have not been clearly described nor defined for post-cardiac arrest syndrome (PCAS) patients undergoing therapeutic hypothermia (TH).

TABREF209.text: ). Demographic information, initial rhythm, and comorbid conditions were obtained. Study variables were abstracted at baseline, 12, 24, 36, and 48 hrs. Variables recorded were systolic blood pressure (SBP) at baseline; MAP at each time point; worst, highest, and lowest mean arterial pressure (MAP) for each 24 hr interval; and vasopressor use.Results: A total of 111 patients were enrolled. Patients were 61 AE 16.8 years, 59.5% male, with an initial rhythm of VF/VT in 50.5% of cases. The initial SBP for patients with good vs. poor outcome was 150 AE 37 mmHg vs. 128 AE 32 mmHg respectively (p=0.037). Patients in both groups had comparable MAPs at 12 hrs (91 vs. 87, p= 0.34) and at 36 hrs (86 vs. 81, p=0.113); however, vasopressor use at these time points differed. At 12 hrs, vasopressors were used in 20% of patients with good outcome, versus 43.4% of patients with poor outcome (p=0.017). At 36 hrs, 31.4% of patients with a good outcome were on vasopressors vs. 50.7% with a poor outcome (p=0.06). In the first 24 hrs, subjects with good and poor outcomes had equal distributions of their worst MAPs into the "low" (90 mmHg) categories. Similarly, in the second 24 hrs, patients with poor outcomes had a similar proportion of patients where their worst MAP was "low" versus those who had a good outcome (67% vs. 76%, ns).Conclusion:Patients with poor neurologic outcomes have lower initial SBPs and a higher percentage of vasopressor use during TH versus patients with good neurologic outcomes. The Effect of Prehospital Therapeutic Hypothermia on Mortality and Neurologic Outcomes in Out-of-Hospital Cardiac Arrest: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis Benton R. Hunter, Daniel P. O'Donnell, Kacy L. Allgood, and Rawle A. Seupaul Indiana University School of Medicine, Indianapolis, IN Background: In-hospital therapeutic hypothermia has been shown to improve survival and neurologic outcome at hospital discharge in patients suffering out-of-hospital cardiac arrest. It has been proposed that earlier cooling provides additive benefit.Objectives: Test the hypothesis that survival and neurologic outcome is improved if therapeutic hypothermia is initiated in the prehospital setting versus in-hospital cooling for patients who have suffered an out-of-hospital cardiac arrest.

TABREF210.text: Results are reported as RR with 95% CIs.Conclusion: Based on data from currently available randomized trials, initiation of hypothermia in the prehospital setting does not offer additional benefits to patients that have suffered an out-of-hospital cardiac arrest.Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, TX;University of Chicago, Chicago, IL Background: The induction of therapeutic hypothermia (TH) in comatose survivors of out-of-hospital cardiac arrest (OHCA) improves survival and neurologic recovery outcomes. Despite results from highquality randomized control trials and international consensus statements, TH utilization rates remain low. Prehospital activation of specialized care teams improves outcomes at trauma, ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction, and stroke receiving centers.

TABREF211.text: : Clinical characteristics of patients in the PRE (n = 46) and POST (n = 63) intervention periods were similar. The eCART activation system was utilized for 97% of OHCA cases presenting to the emergency department. Rate of return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC) was significantly higher during the POST vs. PRE period (37% vs. 17%, p < 0.05). Initiation of TH in eligible patients was also significantly higher during the POST vs. PRE period (100% vs. 80%, p < 0.05). No difference in the time from ROSC to TH goal temperature <34 degrees Celsius (201 min +/-125 vs. 212 min +/-81, p >0.05) or cardiac catheterization laboratory utilization (43% vs. 50%, p > 0.05) was noted between POST and PRE periods respectively.Conclusion: Prehospital activation of an eCART team is associatedwith improvements in ROSC rate and tended to increase TH utilization. These results suggest that rapid deployment of a specialized cardiac arrest response team to the emergency department may be an effective strategy for improving OHCA resuscitation. Additional work is needed to determine if the eCART system has any effect on survival after cardiac arrest.Background: Previous studies report that prolonged downtime in cardiac arrest is associated with poor neurologic outcome. With advancements in post-cardiac arrest care and high-quality CPR, survival after prolonged cardiac arrest may be possible; however, these survival rates have not been well described.

TABREF212.text: ACADEMIC EMERGENCY MEDICINE • May 2013, Vol. 20, No. 5, Suppl 1• www.aemj.org  S133    Methods: A prospective observational study conducted from 01/2008 to 09/2012. Inclusion criteria consisted of adult non-traumatic out-ofhospital cardiac arrest patients who were comatose after return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC) and received therapeutic hypothermia. The primary outcome was neurologic outcome based solely on downtime. The secondary outcome was neurologic outcome based on downtime and initial rhythm. Downtime was defined as the time the patient was recognized as being pulseless to the time of ROSC. Good neurologic outcome was defined as a cerebral performance category (CPC) score of 1 or 2. Patients were divided into four groups based on downtime (figure). Simple descriptive statistics were used to describe the study population. We used Wilcoxon rank sum test to compare downtime between groups.Conclusion: Patients with prolonged cardiac arrest can have meaningful neurologically intact survival even after downtimes of greater than 30 minutes when comprehensive post-arrest treatment (inclusive of hypothermia) is provided. Neurologically intact survival among those with shockable rhythms is even more substantial with a 40% neurologically intact survival rate after 30 minutes of arrest time.

TABREF213.text: Abstract 322 323 National Trends in the Use of Post-Cardiac Arrest Therapeutic Hypothermia and Factors Influencing Utilization Scott Dresden, Lanty O'Connor, Charles Pearce, D Mark Courtney, and Emilie Powell Northwestern University, Chicago, IL Background: Therapeutic hypothermia (TH) in cardiac arrest with return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC) continues to be underutilized in the United States despite established neuroprotective benefits and endorsement by the American Heart Association in 2005. Objectives: The objective of this study is to investigate trends in TH utilization and hospital factors associated with utilization, in United States hospitals across 2007-2010. Methods: Cross-sectional analysis of 117,419 adult hospitalizations with cardiac arrest (ICD-9 427.5 or 799.1) in the 2007-2010 Nationwide Inpatient Sample (NIS). TH was identified by ICD-9 code 780.65 or procedure code 99.81, and yearly utilization of TH as a proportion of all cardiac arrests was calculated. Extrapolation to nationwide yearly estimates of cardiac arrest and TH utilization was done using NIS weighting and differences evaluated with Wald test for linear hypothesis. Logistic regression of TH utilization adjusted for year, patient age and sex, and hospital factors (bed size, ownership, location, region, teaching status, and safety-net status). Results: National yearly estimates of in-hospital cardiac arrest remained stable across 2007-2010: 139,225 to 148,460 to 146,341 to 149,400 in 2010 (Wald test p=0.74). TH utilization in cardiac arrest increased: 0.32% to 0.70% to 1.71% to 2.35% in 2010 (Wald test p<0.01). The proportion of hospitals using TH increased: 4.5% to 9.0% to 18.3% to 22.7% in 2010. Factors with a significant association with TH use Conclusion: Overall utilization of TH relative to all cardiac arrests was very low (<3%), likely reflecting both low overall rates of ROSC in cardiac arrest and low rates of utilization of TH in cardiac arrest with ROSC. Despite a seven-fold increase in the use of TH since 2007, there continue to be significant geographic and hospital factors associated with variability in implementation. Future interventions to determine reasons for underutilization of TH and promote its use might best be focused on non-teaching, safety-net hospitals, in the midwest and south. Scribes in the Emergency Department: What is the Effect on Facility Charges? Justin M. Rodgers, Kevin Broyles, Christopher D. Gatens, Chad E. Burton, and John H. Burton Carilion Clinic, Roanoke, VA Background: The effect of emergency medicine (EM)

TABREF214.text: : There were approximately 8000 ED visits per month during each of the study periods. Mean number of visits and admissions were similar in both periods. The proportion of time during which the ED was considered "Dangerously Overcrowded" decreased by 33.2% after surge-plan implementation, from 33.25% to 0.3% (p<0.001). The proportion of time in "Severely Overcrowded" decreased by 27.1% (p<0.001). Average ED LOS decreased from 11.7 hours to 8.5 hours (difference of 3.2 hours, p<0.001). The number of patients LWBS also diminished by 580 patients between the two study periods.Conclusion: Implementation of a hospital-wide patient surge plan led to significant decreases in daily ED crowding with diminished LOS and improved LWBS rates. Considerable improvement in patient throughput can be obtained by developing an institutional response to daily crowding that simulates adjustments in standard operating procedures found in other disaster response plans. William C. Krauss, Richard H. Chen, James J.Ellingson, and Daniel L. Meltzer Kaiser Permanente, San Diego, CA Background: Patients who present to the emergency department (ED) with abdominal pain requiring computed tomography (CT) imaging are conventionally administered both oral and intravenous (IV) contrast. Several studies investigating the diagnostic accuracy of CT imaging with IV contrast alone, in the abdominal pain patient, have demonstrated no significant difference when compared to those scanned with both IV and oral contrast. Oral contrast is poorly tolerated in the abdominal pain patient and frequently leads to patient discomfort, necessitating further medications with resultant diagnostic delay and increased cost.

TABREF215.text: Objectives: To determine whether implementation of a sepsis screening Computerized Decision Support System (CDSS) led to an increase in ED screening for hyperlactatemia.

TABREF216.text: The primary outcome was lactate testing in the ED; secondary outcomes were time to lactate test result (from ED triage) and diagnosis of hyperlactatemia. Change between study time periods was estimated with logistic and Cox proportional hazards models adjusting for demographics, illness severity [Rapid Emergency Medicine Score (REMS)], and clustering by physician.Results: 2331 patients met inclusion criteria (1168 pre-alert and 1163 post-alert); 95 were hyperlactatemic. After adjustment for potential confounding, patients in the post-alert group were more likely to have lactate testing in the ED [odds ratio (OR)=1.43, 95%CI 1.19, 1.73]. Lactate results were available faster in the post-alert group (median 0.8 hrs, IQR 0.6, 1.3), than the pre-alert group (median 1.9 hrs, IQR 1.4, 3.0) (hazard ratio 1.54, (95%CI 1.35, 1.76). However, patients were no more likely to be diagnosed with hyperlactatemia in the post-alert group (post-alert vs pre-alert OR=0.75, 95%CI 0.47, 1.18).Conclusion: Implementation of a CDSS for sepsis was associated with faster and more reliable screening for hyperlactatemia (in accordance with guidelines). However, there were not more cases of hyperlactatemia found after CDSS initiation.Background: Atrial fibrillation (AF) is the most common cardiac arrhythmia treated in the ED, leading to high rates of hospitalization and resource utilization. Dedicated atrial fibrillation clinics offer the possibility of reducing the admission burden for AF patients presenting to the ED. While the referral base for these AF clinics is growing, it is unclear to what extent these clinics contribute to reducing the number of ED visits and hospitalizations related to AF.

TABREF217.text: Background: Atrial fibrillation (AF) affects up to 6 million Americans with estimated national incremental health care costs of up to $26 billion. ED visits for AF nearly doubled between 1993 and 2004. A lack of evidence-based ED guidelines for treating AF and proponents for both rate and rhythm control treatments may contribute to regional differences in AF management and disposition strategies.Objectives: We hypothesized that ED visits for AF continue to rise and are associated with considerable regional variability in disposition strategies and use of cardioversion. To test this aim, we computed the counts of ED visits from 2006-2009 in patients with a primary diagnosis of AF and the percentage that were hospitalized and cardioverted, by United States (US) geographic regions.Methods: The Nationwide Emergency Department Sample (NEDS)database is a 20% stratified sample of US hospital-based EDs and the largest source of US ED data. We performed a retrospective, cohort analysis of patients who had AF (using the ICD-9 code of 427.31) listed as their primary ED diagnosis in the 2006-2009 NEDS. We calculated the weighted numbers of ED visits, demographics, ED disposition and cardioversions stratified by four US regions: Northeast, Midwest, South, and West. The percentage of AF patients hospitalized was higher in the Northeast and South than in the Midwest and was lowest in the West (seefigure). The percentage of AF patients who underwent ED cardioversion was highest in Midwest and lowest in the South (seefigure).Conclusion: Annual nationwide ED visits for AF continued to increase from 2006 to 2009, resulting in frequent hospitalizations. Over the 4 years of analysis the lowest percentage of AF ED patients were hospitalized in the West than other regions. The percentage of patients undergoing ED cardioversion continues to remain low with the fewest ED cardioversions performed in the South. Clear guidelines for managing AF in the ED may aid physicians and result in a more standardized AF treatment and disposition.

TABREF218.text: Background: The ability to accurately risk-stratify ED patients with atrial fibrillation (AF) and atrial flutter (AFL) is poor. AF and AFL often occur together and cardiology guidelines group the two arrhythmias together for performance measures. More than 65% of ED visits for AF in the United States result in admission and contribute to health care costs of up to $26 billion. The ED return rate within 7 days among discharged patients is 3 -5%, suggesting current criteria used to identify patients safe for discharge are deficient.Objectives: As a first step in developing an AF and AFL disposition decision aid, we describe the incidence of 5-day and 30-day adverse events in ED patients who present for symptomatic AF and AFL.Methods: We performed a prospective, observational cohort study and enrolled ED patients at a single urban, academic, tertiary care referral center who had a new or established ED diagnosis of AF or AFL, confirmed on ECG, as well as signs (e.g. tachycardia, dyspnea) or symptoms (e.g. palpitations, chest pain, shortness of breath, syncope) believed related to AF or AFL. Patients were excluded if they sought ED treatment for complaints not related to AF or AFL. Our composite primary outcome was determined by phone follow-up at 5 and 30 days after the ED visit and included the outcomes listed in the table. 6%) were hospitalized on the initial ED visit. ED electrical cardioversion occurred in 13 (2.9%) patients. Adverse events occurred in 163 (36.9%) patients including 40 (9%) with events within 5 days, 94 (21.3%) with events between 6 -30 days, and 29 (6.6%) who had adverse events both in 0 -5 days and 6 -30 days. The table provides a detailed listing of the adverse events.Conclusion: Despite high hospitalization rates, 37% of ED patients with symptomatic AF and AFL experience adverse events within 30 days including nearly 10% of patients with events within 5 days. Such data are an important consideration as we move forward with development of an AF and AFL disposition decision aid.

TABREF219.text: Abstract 331: 5-Day and 30-Day Adverse Events Adaptation of a Disease-Specific Research Instrument for Quality of Life Assessments in Emergency Department Patients with Atrial Fibrillation/Flutter Nimmie Singh 1 , Adina S. Rauchwerger 1 , Mary E. Reed 1 , Uli K. Chettipally 2 , Dustin G. Mark 3 , Steven R. Offerman 4 , David R. Vinson 5 , and Dustin W. Ballard 6Background: The Atrial Fibrillation Effect on QualiTy-of-life (AFEQT) is a novel disease-specific quality-of-life (QoL) instrument for patients with atrial fibrillation/flutter (AF/F). The AFEQT questionnaire, which evaluates a patient's perception of his or her AF/F symptoms, physical function, and emotional health, can serve as a marker of quality of care. To date, there are no reports of its practical performance.

TABREF220.text: : Among 1539 patients with newly diagnosed or recent-onset AF/F, 1157 (75%) were eligible for an interview. Of these, 986 (85%) were interviewed. Thirty-four (3%) refused to participate; 93 (8%) were lost to follow-up. Reasons for refusal included discomfort with discussing health and informed choice not to participate in research. The average time per call in a sample of 483 patients was 10.5 minutes (IQR 4). From the 986 interviews completed, there are 932 unique survey respondents whose characteristics are shown in the table. Their mean age is 69 years(IQR 19).

TABREF221.text: Abstract 332: Characteristics of 932 survey respondents Background: Syncope represents up to 2% of ED visits and there is great interest in accurately risk stratifying these patients. A single BNP has had little effect on risk stratification.

TABREF222.text: 334AssociationBetween Multiple Needlesticks and Patient Pain Levels in the Emergency Department Nicole Piela, Lauren Freid, Leah Davis, Masashi Rotte, Bon S. Ku, and J. Matthew Fields Thomas Jefferson University, Philadelphia, PA

TABREF223.text: Abstract 334: Demographics of single needle-stick (SNS) and multiple needle-stick (MNS) patient groups 335 Lidocaine Infiltration by Injection vs. Topical LET Gel for Anesthesia for Incision and Drainage of Cutaneous Abscesses: A Randomized Controlled Study Mark K. Ellis, Jha'nee Stoffer, Allison Lane, Brett Coolman, Kristi Grall, Dan Hayes, and Uwe Stoltz University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ Background: The majority of abscess incision and drainage (I&D)

TABREF224.text: The Effect of Vapocoolant Spray on Pain Due to Venipuncture In Adults: A Randomized, Blinded, Placebo-controlled Trial Sharon Mace Cleveland Clinic, Cleveland, OH Objectives: This study determines that a topical vapocoolant spray is effective and safe in adults undergoing venipuncture in the ED.

TABREF225.text: Abstract 336: Summary of Pain Assessments for Saline and Vapocoolant GroupsBackground: Adults presenting for care to an emergency department (ED) often require intravenous catheter (IV) placement. Prior studies suggest that successful IV placement may require up to three sticks. Successfully placing an IV requires identification of appropriate venous access targets. The VeinViewer Vision (VVV) is a medical device that assists with IV placement by projecting a map of subcutaneous veins on the surface of the skin using near infrared light.

TABREF226.text: : 149 patients completed the study. Clinicians were able to respectively; significantly more veins on the ventral forearm using VVV than S alone or S+P, 2.29 (p<0.0001, CI 1.84-2.74) and 2.17 (p<0.0001, CI 1.75-2.60), respectively; and significantly more veins in the antecubital fossa using VVV than S alone or S+P,3.17 (p<0.0001,) and3.19 (p<0.0001,), respectively. The differences in numbers of veins identified remained significant at p<0.05 level across all races and BMI categories and across clinicians.Conclusion: Experienced emergency clinicians were able to identify significantly more veins appropriate for IV placement in the dorsum of the hand, ventral forearm, and antecubital fossa of adults presenting for treatment using VVV than using the standard approaches of S or S+P.Prevalence and Characteristics of Patients Presenting with Difficult Venous Access to the Emergency Department J. Matthew Fields, Nicole E. Piela, Arthur Au, Courtney Townshend, Kaitlyn Dalsey, and Bon S. Ku Thomas Jefferson University, Philadelphia, PA Background: Many patients have difficult venous access (DVA)requiring multiple attempts at IV placement, which may lead to delays in care. The true prevalence of DVA in the ED and its associated characteristics have not been previously described.Objectives: To determine the prevalence and associated factors of DVA in ED patients.Methods:We performed a prospective observational study of patients presenting to an urban academic teaching hospital with an annual census of 65,000. Patients were included if they had an IV placed. Data were collected by trained research associates who interviewed patients immediately after successful IV placement during periods of block enrollment from July through October 2012. Patients were excluded if complete data were not obtained or if they refused consent. The primary outcome was the presence of DVA, defined as three or more attempts for successful IV placement or if a back-up method of IV placement was performed (external jugular or ultrasound guidance). In addition to demographic data, the following medical conditions (which have previously been thought to be associated with DVA) were collected: obesity, diabetes, dialysis, sickle cell disease, upper extremity swelling, visit to ED or hospital in the past 90 days, history of chemotherapy, or IV drug abuse (IVDA). Univariate analysis was performed using chi-square or Fisher's exact test to determine factors associated with DVA. Significant variables were then tested in a multivariate logistical regression model.Results: 548 patients met inclusion criteria, of whom 23 were excluded due to incomplete data. The prevalence of DVA was 12.8% (95CI 9.9-15.6%). Demographics and patient characteristics for DVA vs. non-DVA patients are presented in the table and graphically in the figure. History of IVDA (OR 3.1, 95CI 1.3-7.8), sickle cell diease (OR 3.3, 95CI 1.1-9.9), and swelling of the upper extremities (OR 1.9, 95CI 1.2-5.2) were significant predictors of DVA in a logistic regression model.Conclusion: DVA affects nearly 13% of ED patients and is more common in patients with a history of IVDA, sickle cell disease, and swelling in the upper extremities. Interestingly, DVA was not significantly higher in patients with obesity or on dialysis.

TABREF227.text: Abstract 338: Patient demographics and characteristics with and without difficult venous access Prevalence of Needle Phobia in Patients with Difficult Venous Access Leah A. Davis, Bon S. Ku, Brittany Griffin, and J. Matthew Fields Thomas Jefferson University, Philadelphia, PA

TABREF228.text: Methods:We performed a prospective observational study of patients presenting to an urban academic teaching hospital with an annual census of 65,000. Data were collected by trained research associates who interviewed patients towards the end of their ED stays during periods of block enrollment from July through October 2012. Patients were excluded if complete data were not obtained. Patients were asked if they have a fear of needles or if they have extreme anxiety at the thought of being stuck with a needle for blood draw or IV placement. The definition of NP was adapted from the DSM IV criteria for specific phobia as a fear of needles or if the patient felt extreme unwarranted fear or anxiety when told he or she would need to be stuck with a needle. History of DVA was defined as a reported history of requiring MNS (3 or more) for IV access or an ultrasound-guided IV or an IV placed in the neck. Univariate analysis was performed using Pearson's chi-square or Fisher's exact test where appropriate.Results: 720 patients were enrolled; 21 patients were excluded due to incomplete survey data leaving 699 for data analysis. Data on patient demographics and NP prevalence are presented in the table. 36% (95CI 33-40%) of patients met criteria for NP either admitting to a fear of needles, 26%, or severe anxiety at the idea of having a needle placed, 29%.Conclusion:The prevalence of NP may be higher in the ED than the general population. NP does not appear to be more prevalent in patients with previous DVA.

TABREF229.text: ACADEMIC EMERGENCY MEDICINE • May 2013, Vol. 20, No.  5, Suppl 1• www.aemj.org S141 The Potability of and Analysis of Sterilization Techniques of Fresh Water Sources Bordering The Flood Plain Of South Long Island, NY and Queens, NY Shiau Hui Chin 1 , Sanjey Gupta 1 , and Jay Lemery 2 New York Hospital Queens, Flushing, NY; Weill Cornell Medical College, New York, NYBackground: Natural and man-made disasters result in disruption of public sectors utilities and destruction of essential infrastructure. In several coastal communities in NY and NJ, Superstorm Sandy disrupted all public utilities, including electricity, natural gas, sewage treatment, and fresh water delivery, for extended periods of time.

TABREF230.text: Methods: This prospective, in vivo, basic science study involved two phases. First, six fresh water samples were collected sites near the flood plain in southern LI and eastern Qu: (a)Massapequa preserve, (b) All samples were sterilely handled and plated in triplicate on Coliscan Easygel agar plates and incubated at 95°F for 48 hours. Colony counts for E. coli and coliforms were conducted and results were stored and analyzed with Microsoft Excel 2010.Results: All samples, except for the tap water, were contaminated with E. coli and fecal coliforms. Location-specific coliforms: 12 cfu/mL (site a); 34 cfu/mL (site b); 37.3 cfu/mL (site c); 95.6 cfu/mL (site d); 54.5 cfu/mL (site e), 34.33 cfu/mL (site f). In the second phase of sterilization treatments: bleach (0 cfu/mL total coliforms or E. coli); ETOH (coliform 90 cfu/mL & 5.66 cfu/mL E. coli); coffee filter(coliform 79.33 cfu/mL & 4 cfu/mL E. coli); Brita (coliform 71.33 cfu/mL & 2 cfu/mL E. coli). ANOVA coliforms p=0.019, Tukey test p<0.05 control vs. bleach. ANOVA E. coli p<0.001, Tukey test p<0.05 control vs. all test samples.

TABREF231.text: Background: On October 29, 2012, Hurricane Sandy struck the northern New Jersey area and caused injury, death, property damage, and left millions of people without power for up to two weeks. The effects of a storm like this on prehospital advanced life support (ALS) calls and treatments in a suburban area like northern New Jersey are unknown.Objectives: We sought to quantify the change in weekly ALS volume after the storm and examine the percent of calls that were cancelled prior to ALS arrival, triaged to basic life support (BLS), and treated by ALS compared to baseline.Methods: Design: Retrospective cohort. Setting: A large, suburban, hospital-based EMS system that responds to approximately 26,000 calls per year. Protocol: Weekly ALS call volume was calculated for the four weeks before October 29 to establish baseline volume. Calls were reviewed to determine if ALS was cancelled prior to evaluating the patient, if the patient was triaged to BLS, or if the patient was treated by ALS. 95% confidence intervals (CI) were calculated for baseline data. Weekly data for the two weeks after the hurricane were calculated and compared to baseline.Results: For the four weeks prior to Sandy, there were an average of 395 (CI: 376, 414) ALS calls per week. Of these, 44% (CI: 42, 46) were cancelled prior to ALS arrival and 12% (CI: 10, 14) were triaged to BLS. The percent of the total calls that were treated by ALS was 39% (CI: 37, 40) and the percent of non-cancelled calls that were transported was69%  (CI: 67, 71). Compared to before the storm, in the two weeks after the storm there was a statistically significant increase in weekly ALS calls received (Week 1: 473 calls, 20% above baseline, p<0.01; Week 2: 418 calls, 6% above baseline, p<0.05). There were no differences in age or sex. The percent of total patients treated each week was unchanged (Week 1: 37%, Week 2: 38%), and there were no significant changes in the percent of patients who were triaged to BLS (Week 1: 14%, Week 2: 14%).Conclusion: After a major destructive storm, the volume of ALS requests increases significantly. The number of calls in which a patient is treated by ALS providers increases proportionately. There appears to be no difference in acuity of the calls because there is no change in the percent of calls that are cancelled or triaged to BLS.Hurricane Sandy: The Effect of Multiple ED Closures on Patient Volume and Acuity Saadia Akhtar, Tom Nguyen, Paul Krieger, John Irwin, Gregg Husk, and Michael Heller Beth Israel Medical Center, New York, NY

TABREF232.text: Background: Natural disasters can have a tremendous effect on prehospital providers. On October 29, 2012, Hurricane Sandy hit northern New Jersey leaving many homeless or without power for weeks.Objectives: We sought to describe the changes in types of calls for which advanced life support (ALS) was requested after Hurricane Sandy struck the area.Methods: Design: Retrospective cohort. Setting: A large, suburban,

TABREF233.text: : During the study period, 2433 patients received examination at the shelter clinics. Four hundred twenty seven patients (17.6%) were excluded due to insufficient medical records. The average patient age was about 53.6 years old. The number of patients per day was 93.1 which amounts to approximately 4% of all evacuees. The number of patients was peaked between March 28 and April 3, when 411 patients per 1000 evacuees visited shelter clinic per week. Most common diagnoses were upper respiratory infection (n=478 per 1000 evacuees), minor trauma and musculoskeletal disorder (n=65.4 per 1000 evacuees), and sleep disorder (n=59.8 per 1000 evacuees) (table).Conclusion: After Great Japan Earthquake and Tsunami, half of evacuees in shelter ware affected with upper respiratory infection.

TABREF234.text: Abstract 344: Number of cases visited the shelter clinic per 1000 evacuees. Keck School of Medicine at the University of Southern California, Los Angeles, CA; 4 Los Angeles County Emergency Medical Services Agency, Santa Fe Springs, CA Background: Prehospital identification of STEMI and activation of the catheterization lab can improve door-to-balloon (DTB) times but may lead to decreased specificity and unnecessary use of important resources. Objectives: To examine the effect of ECG transmission on DTB times and false-positive (FP) field activations in a large metropolitan area.Methods: This is a retrospective cohort study of data from a single registry in a large metropolitan area with regionalized cardiac care and EMS providers with ECG transmission capabilities. Thirty-three designated STEMI receiving centers (SRC) contribute to this registry, from which patients with a prehospital ECG indicating a STEMI were identified between July 1 and December 31, 2011. DTB times and rate of FP activations (defined as not resulting in emergent PCI or referral for CABG) for patients with ECG transmission received by the SRC were compared to a reference group who did not have successful ECG transmission. The protocol for cath lab activation for prehospital STEMI varied by institution.Results: There were 1582 patients who presented with prehospital ECGs indicating STEMI. The ECGs were received by the SRC for 346 (22%) of these patients, whereas the ECGs were not received for 1234 patients (78%). Regardless of ECG transmission, the cath lab was activated 84% of the time, with 74% and 80% of activations initiated prior to ED arrival in the transmission group and reference group, respectively. The overall proportion of FP activation was 50%.In the reference group, the FP rate was significantly increased with prehospital activation compared to ED activation, 55% vs. 37% (risk difference = 18%, 95%CI 10 to 25%). However, when ECG transmission was completed, there was a similar FP rate for activations in the ED of 45% and this did not increase with prehospital activation at 43% (risk difference = -2%, 95%CI -16 to 11). ECG transmission significantly reduced the overall rate of FP activations, 44% vs. 52%, risk difference = 8%, 95%CI 2 to 14). The RR of FP activation when the ECG transmission was received versus not received was 0.85, 95% CI 0.76 to 0.96 (p=0.01). ECG transmission had no significant effect on DTB times with 96% of patients meeting the 90-minute goal. Conclusion: Prehospital ECG transmission is associated with a reduced rate of false-positive activations for STEMI. of a Medical Toxicology Telemedicine Consult Service to Assist Physicians Serving Overseas: 2005-2012 Joseph K. Maddry 1 , Vikhyat S. Bebarta 2 , Kennon J. Heard 1 , Daniel J. Sessions 1 , John G. McManus 3 , and Charles M. Lappan 4Background: Specialty care (such as medical toxicology) is not readily available to military and civilian physicians in overseas contingency operations. The US Army Medical Department designed an electronic mail telemedicine system in 2004 to provide consultations for remote health care providers. The service provides e-consultation 24 hours/day to assist government providers managing cases in austere environments.Objectives: To describe the types and the frequency of toxicology Methods: Consults were generated using the military electronic mail system routed to on-call military, medical toxicologists. A project manager monitored all teleconsultations to ensure Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act compliance, and consultants' recommendations were transmitted within a 24-hour mandated time period. A single, unblinded data extractor reviewed all medical toxicology consultations from July 2005-July 2012 and recorded the frequency of each type of predefined consultation using a standardized collection form.Results: Ninety-eight e-consults were performed over 7 years. The majority of consultations came from physicians in Iraq (44%) and Afghanistan (36%). The average reply time was 4 hours (range 0.06 to 29.18 hours). Seventy-six consultations involved patient interactions and 22 were for general management protocols. The 76 patient consultations included 59 US military patients, 3 US contractors, 14 local nationals, and 7 pediatric. The most common consultation was for snake envenomation and antivenom recommendations (22%; 95% CI 15% to 32%) followed by accidental chemical exposures (14%; 95% CI 9% to 23%), drug testing (13%; 95% CI 8% to 21%), and substance abuse (10%; 95% CI 6% to 18%). Other consultations were for intentional overdoses, scorpion envenomations, occupational exposures, and withdrawal syndromes.Conclusion: Physicians providing care to patients in Iraq andAfghanistan should be trained in management of envenomations, chemical exposures, and drug abuse and testing. Teleconsultation can be used to assist in the management of patients when clinicians require specialist consultation. Development of a similar volunteer teleconsultation program could assist physicians serving in austere locations throughout the world.Background: The implementation of electronic patient care reports (ePCR) in EMS has many implications for EMS systems and providers.

TABREF235.text: Conclusion:Despite recently published concerns held by lead EMS agencies in the U.S., implementation of ePCR does not increase turnaround time. Our study found a small but statistically significant reduction in ambulance turnaround time after the implementation of an ePCR. Further multi-agency studies should confirm this reduction in turnaround time and address other potential effects of ePCR implementation.

TABREF236.text: Demographic matching was successful for 4,025 patients (95.9%; 95%CI 95.3%-96.5%). There were 5,137 ePCR views during the study period. 2,323 (57.7%) of patients had their ePCRs queried at least once and 1,280 (31.8%) had their ePCRs queried more than once. 33.0% of queries were by residents, 9.9% were attending physicians, 3.9% were by medical students, 18.6% were by nurses, and 34.6% were by others such as consultants and primary care providers.Conclusion: Real-time clinical data sharing between an ePCR system and an Emergency Department Information System is feasible and should not be considered a barrier to widespread ePCR implementation as suggested by a recent publication. Future studies will be needed to identify opportunities to improve information sharing between providers and decrease communication errors during transitions of care.Background: Clopidogrel is used for both primary and secondary thromboprophylaxis. Warfarin increases the risk of intracranial injury following trauma; aspirin does not. The risk of intracranial injury in patients with head trauma on clopidogrel is unclear. Due to this uncertainty, it is often standard practice to obtain head CTs for patients on clopidogrel who sustain minor head trauma.

TABREF237.text: 350TheMortality and Severity of Bleeding in Trauma Patients Taking Dabigatran Zachary DW Dezman 1 , John Hess 2 , Angela Comer 3 , and Jon Mark Hirshon 1 1 Department of Emergency Medicine, University of Maryland, Baltimore, MD; 2 Department of Pathology, University of Maryland, Baltimore, MD; 3 National Study Center for Trauma and Emergency Medical Systems, Baltimore, MD Background: Emergency physicians commonly care for patients taking hemostasis modifying agents (HMA) like warfarin, aspirin, and clopidogrel.

TABREF238.text: Abstract 35: Demographics of general trauma population during study period.Table 2 -Abstract 350: Mortality and transfusion risk in dabigatran patients compared to matched controls. Background: The 2011 National Trauma Triage Protocol Field Triage Decision Scheme identifies anti-coagulant and bleeding disorders as special considerations for triage of patients to trauma centers. Little prospective data exist to justify this standard. Objectives: To evaluate anticoagulants as independent risk factors for trauma center need for EMS trauma patients. Methods: We conducted a secondary analysis of a prospective observational study of EMS trauma patients transported to three Level I trauma centers from March 2007 to March 2009. EMS personnel were interviewed upon hospital arrival to capture variables related to their injury.

TABREF239.text: table demonstrates frequencies and ORs of outcome by drug category (vs no drug). Patients age >55 (157, 6.2%, OR 2.18, 95% CI 1.73, 2.75) needed a trauma center. When controlling for age>55, drug use did not increase trauma center need.Conclusion: Although limited by low rate of injured patients with medication use, among trauma patients who do not meet anatomic, physiologic, or mechanism of criteria for Level I triage, anticoagulant and antiplatelet drugs portend an increase in trauma center need. However, when controlling for age, medication use did not independently predict trauma center need.

TABREF240.text: Abstract 351Background: The anticoagulant dabigatran has no reversal agent and may cause life-threatening bleeding in patients with trauma or closed space hemorrhage. Intravenous lipid emulsion (ILE) is thought to create a lipid compartment in serum that sequesters lipophilic drugs. Dabigatran is lipophilic and its anticoagulant effects are concentrationdependent.Objectives: To determine if ILE therapy reverses dabigatran's anticoagulant effects.Methods: Twenty rats were randomized, 10 in the ILE group, and 10 in a normal saline (NS) control group. Animals had baseline tail bleeding times (T0) followed by oral dabigatran administration (15mg/ kg). At 45 minutes (T45), a second tail bleeding time was performed, followed by a 7 minute intravenous infusion of 15 ml/kg of ILE or NS. A final 60 minute (T60) bleeding time was obtained. An ILE-only group of five animals had bleeding times assessed prior to (T0) and 15 minutes after (T15) ILE therapy. Comparisons were made using t-tests.Results: Between T0 and T45, average bleeding times increased from 109.5 seconds [95% CI 94-125] to 231.8 seconds [95% CI 193-271] (p<0.0001). Between T45 and T60, bleeding times in the ILE group decreased by 31.5 seconds [95% CI -77 to +14] and by 6 seconds [95% CI -67 to +55] in the NS group; not statistically significant (p=0.46). In the five ILE-only animals, the average bleeding time at T0 was 114 seconds [95% CI 62-166] which increased significantly at T15 to 237 seconds [95% CI 161-313] (p=0.006). Conclusion: The anticoagulant effects of dabigatran are not reversed with ILE therapy. Although ILE itself significantly prolonged bleeding times, when administered to dabigatran-anticoagulated rats, bleeding times decreased, but not significantly. There may be a complex interaction of ILE with dabigatran that this study was not able to elucidate. Nepal Sneha Shrestha 1 , Benjamin Kelly 2 , Elizabeth Pirrotta 1 , Ashis Shrestha 3 , Rajesh Gongal 3 , Matthew C. Strehlow 1 , and Swaminatha V. Mahadevan 1 1 Stanford School of Medicine, Stanford, CA; 2 Nepal Ambulance Service, Kathmandu, Nepal; 3 Patan Academy of Health Sciences, Lalitpur, Nepal Background: Emergencies pose a significant health burden worldwide, though data are too limited to appreciate the extent of the problem in Nepal.Objectives: To describe the characteristics and outcomes of patients presenting to the emergency department of a teaching hospital in Kathmandu, Nepal.Methods: This prospective, observational study enrolled all ED patients presenting to Patan Hospital over twenty-eight 12-hour periods (equally comprising every hour and day of the week) during June-July, 2011. Researchers, using a standardized questionnaire, collected clinical and demographic data from patients, hospital staff, and medical records in real time. Follow-up data (at 48 hrs and 14 days post ED visit) were collected by phone from patients and family members, or by querying medical records and hospital staff. Multivariate logistic regression was performed to determine factors associated with mortality.Conclusion: In this initial study of ED presentations in Nepal, half of patients presented with either GI or general medical complaints, and injuries were comparatively infrequent. Additionally, relatively low mortality and admission rates suggest that the ED sees a wide spectrum of disease severity.Background: The World Health Organization's IntegratedManagement of Childhood Illnesses (IMCI) guidelines recommend diagnosing pneumonia in children based on respiratory rate in resource-limited settings. While some studies have found respiratory rate to be a moderately good predictor of pneumonia, more recent studies have not found this to be the case.Objectives: To examine the accuracy of clinical factors for diagnosing pediatric pneumonia in a resource-limited setting. We hypothesize that clinical signs and symptoms, such as oxygen saturation, may be better predictors of pneumonia than respiratory rate alone.Methods:We conducted a retrospective chart review of children under five presenting with respiratory complaints to three rural hospitals in Rwanda who received chest radiographs. A data abstraction tool was created to assess for the presence or absence of historical, clinical, and laboratory signs that might be predictive of pneumonia. For each chart, the chest radiograph were reviewed by two separate pediatric radiologists for the presence of pneumonia. Overall correlation and individual test characteristics were calculated for each categorical variable studied against the gold standard of radiologistconfirmed pneumonia. For continuous variables, we created receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves to determine their accuracy for predicting pneumonia.Results: Between May 2011 and April 2012, 147 children under five who received chest x-rays were admitted to our study hospitals with respiratory complaints. Based on our pediatric radiologists, about 58% of children had pneumonia, while 42% did not. Of the categorical variables studied, only history of asthma (chi-square=4.48, p=0.034) and a negative blood smear for malaria (chi-square=6.21, p=0.013) were statistically associated with pneumonia. Of the continuous variables studied, only oxygen saturation had an area under the ROC curve (AUC) statistically different from the reference line (i.e. better than chance), with an AUC of 0.675 (95% CI 0.581, 0.769 and p=0.001). Respiratory rate had an AUC of 0.528 (95% CI 0.428, 0.627 and p=0.588), not significantly different from the reference line.

TABREF241.text: Background: Long waiting times in the emergency department are a source of dissatisfaction, poor quality care and a threat for patient safety. We analyzed the effects of a new concept of ED management on reduction of waiting times (WT) and length of stay (LOS).Objectives: To evaluate the effect of new management by Lean method with the implementation of Triage Team on waiting time and processing time of an emergency department (ED). To assess whether new ED flow management reduces numbers of patients waiting to be seen.Methods: Comparative observational study of ED indicators and parameters during the last 4 years (2007 to 2011) and after 11 months (December to November 2012) of new management in a French general hospital (40,000 visits/year). We analyzed data on waiting time (WT), length of stay (LOS) in the ED, and left without being seen (LWBS). We analyze the effect of triage nurse, physician triage, fast Track, patient flow, and admission rate of ED and Short Stay Unit.Results: After 3 months (March 2012), evidence of decreased LOS by 50 % (8 hours 33 mn to 3h36) was the main effect of the new ED management. The effect of team triage on LWBS was relatively strong. The effect of Fast Track on waiting time, length of stay, and LWBS was strong. Median times were significantly reduced (p<0.05) during the intervention to triage (10 min v 30 min, p = 0. 029), to see a doctor (10 min v 120 min, p<0.05). The admission rate was similar (35 % vs 34 %). The patient leaving without being seen decrease (9 % vs 0.05 %). The admission rate and the LOS of the Short Stay Unit was more efficient with a new management (100% and < 24 hour in 2012 vs 120% and 72 hour in 2011).Conclusion: Actions to reduce overcrowding need new strategies like Lean's method focus on flow orientation, reduction in unnecessary stay in the ED, participation of all co-workers. The main effect of new management with team triage with Fast Track appears to be a decreasing LOS by 50% in a crowded French ED. A new management in the conceptual model of ED by Lean method is beneficial for decreasing the waiting time and length of stay. Fast Track for patients with less severe symptoms results in shorter waiting time, shorter length of stay, and fewer patients leaving without being seen. We need further studies to evaluate the effect of the Lean method on other diagnostic procedures (e.g. laboratory tests and x-rays) on the waiting time and length of stay.The Effect of Suspected Diagnosis on Physician Pretest Probability for Abdominal Pain Patients Undergoing Computed Tomography in the Emergency Department Angela M. Mills, Frances S. Shofer, Olanrewaju A. Soremekun, Elizabeth M. Datner, and Judd E. Hollander University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA

TABREF242.text: : 2527 patients enrolled (mean age 46.4 +/-17.9 years, 62% female, 54% black, 48% admitted). Pretest probability was significantly lower for potentially life threatening diagnoses. The three conditions that received CT with the lowest pretest suspicion were the most potentially life threatening: mesenteric ischemia (36%, 95% CI 26-45%), AAA (37%, 95% CI 26-48%), and perforated viscus (38%, 95% CI 31-44%). By comparison, the three conditions that received CT with the higher pretest suspicion were less likely to be acutely life threatening;Conclusion: Potentially life-threatening diagnoses were more likely to receive abdominal CT at lower pretest probabilities of the condition.Background: Acute upper gastrointestinal (GI) hemorrhage is a common presentation whose severity ranges from benign to lifethreatening and the best tool to risk-stratify the disease is an upper endoscopy (EGD), a procedure performed almost exclusively by gastroenterology physicians. Unfortunately, on-call GI specialists are frequently unavailable and the ED currently lacks a method to visualize suspected acute upper GI hemorrhage. Recent research has shown that video capsule endoscopy is well-tolerated by ED patients and has similar sensitivity and specificity to traditional endoscopy for upper GI hemorrhage.Objectives: Our goal is to determine if ED physicians with brief training in video capsule endoscopy can detect upper GI bleeding on videos.Methods: A survey study was designed to show four examples ofvideo capsule endoscopy to ED physicians. Each physician received training consisting of less than 10 minutes of background information and endoscopy examples in the form of a web-based slide presentation. Following training, the subjects were asked to interpret four videos of capsule endoscopy in patients with suspected upper GI hemorrhage for evidence of bleeding or no bleeding. All videos were generated from a prior ED-based study on patients with suspected acute upper GI hemorrhage. Setting: ED physicians were recruited at the American College of Emergency Physicians Scientific Assembly in Denver, Colorado in the exhibitor hall on 10/8/2012 to 10/10/2012. Response rate was estimated greater than 70%. Subjects: Inclusion criteria for study subjects included being an ED resident or attending physician, and exclusion criteria included formal endoscopy training such as a gastroenterology fellowship. Analysis: We analyzed the agreement between the ED physicians and expert-adjudicated readings for each capsule video. For the outcome categories of blood or no blood detected, the sensitivity and specificity were calculated.

TABREF243.text: 358IsThe Incidence of Intussusception Increasing in the Adult Patient Population and Do Age and Sex Differences Exist? Fred Fiesseler 1 , Renee Riggs 2 , and Dave Salo 1 Background: Intussusception is a pervasive disease with significant morbidity if left untreated. It has long been speculated that this is primarily a disease of pediatric patients. Objectives: To determine the age of those afflicted with this disease and whether this has increased over time and whether differences in age with respect to sex exist. Methods: Design: A multi-center retrospective cohort study. Participants: Consecutive patients with the final ICD9 diagnosis of intussusception from Apr 1999 to Nov 2010. All charts were manually reviewed for specific predetermined data points. Patients were excluded for chart unavailable or incorrect final diagnosis. Statistics: Mann Whitney and chi-square utilizing Yates value, with a significant P-value < 0.05. Results: 8,340,594 patient visits occurred during the study period. 59.3%, 95%CI 54.4-64.1%) occurring between Apr-Sept (p<0.0002). Admission/transfer occurred in 83% (N=349).

TABREF244.text: Abstract 358Background: Cholelithiasis affects an estimated 20 million people in the United States yearly, and 20% of symptomatic patients will eventually develop acute cholecystitis (AC). A recent single-center study estimated the test characteristics of bedside ultrasonography (BUS) for the diagnosis of AC, as defined by gallstones plus sonographic Murphy's sign or pericholecystic fluid or gallbladder wall thickening, and resulted in a sensitivity and specificity of 87% (95% CI 66-97) and 82% (95% CI 74-88), respectively. It has been previously shown that BUS has excellent sensitivity for gallstones.Objectives: We hypothesized that the finding of gallstones alone on BUS would have excellent sensitivity and negative predictive value as a screening test for AC. The objective of the current study was to estimate the test characteristics of such a screening test as defined by the presence or absence of gallstones alone, with the purpose of reliably excluding AC in ambulatory patients.Methods:We conducted a secondary data analysis of a prospective observational study conducted at an urban academic ED that estimated the test characteristics of BUS for the diagnosis for AC. A convenience sample of adults was enrolled between May 2006 and February 2008. Presence or absence of gallstones on BUS was compared to surgical histo-pathological reports as the gold standard. All ultrasounds were performed by the treating physicians: attending, fellow, or resident.Results: During the study period, 193 patients were enrolled; 23 were lost to follow up, 2 did not receive US, 2 had US performed by medical students, and 2 had unavailable pathology reports; 164 patients were included in the final analysis. The overall prevalence of AC was 14% (23 pathology-confirmed cases). Using our narrow screening criteria, BUS for AC had sensitivity of 100% (95% CI 85.Conclusion: These results support the approach that the absence of gallstones allows emergency physicians to exclude the diagnosis of acute cholecystitis. Approximately half of patients (i.e. those with no gallstones) could be reliably excluded from additional studies, thereby allowing for the selective use of scarce resources to patients who are at higher risk of disease.

TABREF246.text: Variability in Pediatric ED Care of Sickle Cell Disease and Fever Angela M. Ellison 1 , Cary Thurm 2 , Shabnam Jain 3 , John Cheng 3 , Evaline Alessandrini 4 , Kelly Black 5 , Lisa Schroeder 6 , Kimberly Stone 5 , and Elizabeth R. Alpern 1 Background: The National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute recommends that children with sickle cell disease (SCD) and fever seek emergent care. Data regarding variability of emergency department (ED) care in this population are limited.

TABREF247.text: Abstract 363Conclusion: Variation in management of patients with SCD and fever occurs mostly with admission rates and is driven by hospital. Future studies exploring the reasons for such wide variation in admission rates is warranted.Background: A sickle cell crisis results in vascular obstruction, leading to local hypoxemia, pain, and sometimes infection. Identifying a bacterial infection early is critical but confirmation through blood cultures may take days.Objectives: This study evaluated whether lactate levels measured in the ED would be associated with having positive blood cultures in pediatric patients with sickle cell disease.Methods: This prospective observational study was conducted at a tertiary care pediatric emergency department with 53,000 visits per year. Consecutive children aged 0-21 years old with SS disease presenting with fever, 100.4F or greater, were eligible for inclusion. Participants were excluded if lactate levels or blood cultures were not performed. Blood cultures and lactate levels are part of routine standing orders in our ED. Data were collected from patients who visited the ED from 9/2009 to 11/2011. The primary outcome measure was positive blood cultures (+BC). Additional variables assessed included reticulocyte count, WBC count, pulse, temperature, age, and lactate levels. Adjusted odds ratios were calculated.Results: There were 224 visits (179 children) that had both lactate levels and blood culture data available and were used for the analysis. The mean temperature (T) in those with +BC was 102.5 (101.8- 103.1)  and in those with -BC was 100.8 (100.5-101.4) (p<0.001). The mean lactate levels in those with +BC was 2.8(2.1-3.6) and in those with -BC was 1.9 (95%CI 1.8-2.1) (p=0.009). The area under the ROC curve for lactate predicting positive blood cultures was 0.68 (95%CI 0.54-0.82). A cut-off of 0.9 for lactate would provide a sensitivity= 100%, specificity= 9%, PPV= 10%, and NPV= 100% for predicting +BC.Conclusion: Lactate was significantly associated with having +BC.This suggests that lactate may help identify bacterial infection early in these patients. A much larger multicenter prospective study would help elucidate these findings Background: Patients with sickle cell disease (SCD) often present to the ED for treatment during vaso-occlusive crises and have reported experiencing negative attitudes from providers.Objectives: We sought to validate a survey that measures attitudes towards SCD patients in a sample of ED providers, and compare differences in attitude scores between provider types.

TABREF248.text: Conclusion:The attitudes survey tool provides a valid measure of ED provider attitudes towards SCD patients. Nurses have higher negative attitudes scores, lower uneasiness with care scores, and lower medical condition regard scores than physicians.

While scoring tools exist, they are either too cumbersome or are only valid in specific environments.Objectives: The purpose of this study is to correlate variables in determining overcrowding in different sized community EDs in California. The hypothesis of this study was that certain variables correlate significantly with ED crowding.

Logistic regression was performed to determine the effect of vessel characteristics on longevity and device failure.Conclusion: Both PW and PG USGMCs allow for catheterization of deep veins with longevity that exceeds that of traditional IVs, regardless of vessel location. TABREF284.text: Background: MVC is a leading cause of death and is responsible for over 2 million annual ED visits. The relative effects of age, body mass index (BMI), and sex on MVC injuries are poorly understood and current injury prevention efforts do not effectively address variability in occupant characteristics.

TABREF285.text: Conclusion: Increasing age, obesity, and sex differences have predictable effects on MVC injuries with the effects of increasing age most significant. Future prevention efforts should increase computational modeling of occupant characteristic variability and consider examining adaptive safety systems that can be tailored to an occupant's age, sex, and BMI to decrease MVC-related injury.

This may be related to dissatisfaction with or inadequate previous care.

TABREF298.text: Abstract 428: Unadjusted Comparison of Mortality, Charges, and Procedures in California Hospitals, 2010Background: There is growing interest amongst public officials and health care managers to develop programs that divert non-emergent patients from the ED to other, presumably less costly, sources of care. Research shows that patients with limited health literacy have more ED visits and fewer doctor office visits than those with higher literacy, but it is unclear if this represents barriers to ambulatory care, patient preference, or need for emergency care.Methods: Observational, cross-sectional study of adults ! 18 years of age presenting to an academic ED from June-August, 2012. The visually and hearing impaired and medically unstable were excluded. Using systematic sampling, patients were approached based on time, day, and mode of arrival of the general ED population. After informed consent, a structured interview assessed literacy (Rapid Estimate of Adult Literacy in Medicine), access to care (Consumer Assessment of Healthcare Providers and Systems surveys), and reasons for ED use (Emergency Medicine Patients' Access to Healthcare tool). Literacy group differences were assessed using chi-square test and JMP9 statistical software.Conclusion: Patients with limited literacy report access to care with their personal doctor as soon as it is needed yet perceive better care in the ED. Patients with limited literacy may also perceive greater need for emergency care but are no more likely to be hospitalized than those with higher literacy. Efforts to divert patients from emergency care may be unsuccessful if patient literacy, attitudes, and preferences are not considered.

TABREF299.text: Objectives: The purpose of this study is to determine the correlation between prescribing rates of specific opiates on the prescription opiate pharmaceutical costs incurred by a state Medicaid system.Conclusion:Although the costs spent on prescription drugs by this single state Medicaid system are staggering, there was no significant correlation between statewide prescribing rates of opiates and Medicaid dollars spent on these individual drugs.Background: Return visits to the ED are a large source of cost and morbidity. Few studies have focused on patterns of return utilization based on chief complaint.

The closure of four EDs in Orange County (OC) from 2002 to 2010, and an increase in the uninsured, has rendered hospitals increasingly overcrowded. Exploring creative ways in which to address this issue has become a necessity.

TABREF308.text: Background: Successful linkage to medical care after HIV diagnosis is crucial for individual and public health outcomes. Our center and others have reported considerable success in linkage, but such reports may be inflated due to crude outcome definitions and limited analysis. Anecdotally, an initial "intake visit" with an infectious diseases center (IDC) does not necessarily denote a full initial evaluation and completed treatment decisions.Objectives: We comprehensively assess linkage from our ED HIV testing program by describing patterns of health care utilization for the year following a positive HIV test result obtained in the ED.Methods: This retrospective cohort study included confirmed HIV positive patients newly diagnosed between 2002 and 2010 in an urban, academic ED in a region of lower HIV prevalence. Linkage procedures included in-person and telephone follow-up, attempts at repeat contact for missed appointments, and accompanying patients to initial appointments. Records from the study-site health system, including the ED, hospital, IDC, and outpatient clinics, were reviewed for the year subsequent to each patient's diagnosis. Primary outcomes were the frequency of IDC linkage and time to IDC linkage. Secondary outcomes included the number and type of non-IDC health care encounters.Conclusion: Actual linkage success for patients diagnosed by EDHIV testing is likely to be modestly less than traditionally reported. This has important implications for public health and the effect of ED HIV screening. Repeat encounters with the health care system after diagnosis represent opportunities for linkage intervention, particularly in EDs.

Respondents displayed less enthusiasm for readily available geriatric specialty ED consultations, physical therapy evaluations, prehospital provider education, quarterly geriatric QI reports to hospital leadership or geriatric QI reports in general, or infrastructural modifications to lighting, colors, or signage.Conclusion: A sample of EM physicians with interest in care of geriatric patients endorsed the domains that define the minimal attributes of a geriatric ED put forward by this multidisciplinary collaboration. Future research is needed to assess the perspectives of community physicians, hospital administrators, and policy makers as the white paper is further refined.Performance of an Emergency Care Telemedicine Program for Older Adults Manish N. Shah, Erin B. Wasserman, Suzanne M. Gillespie, Dallas L. Nelson, Nancy Wood, Matt Doyle, Shirley Li, and Kenneth M. McConnochie University of Rochester, Rochester, NY Background: Accessing timely emergency care is a challenge for older adults residing in senior living communities (SLCs), resulting in potentially avoidable ED visits. We implemented a program that offered emergency care via telemedicine to evaluate complaints triaged to need attention before the next available outpatient visit but not to require ED resources. This option provided patients access to care in their residences. Objectives: To describe the telemedicine program characteristics and to evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of telemedicine to care for older adult SLC residents with emergency care needs. Methods: Telemedicine was made available to patients of a primary care geriatrics practice who resided in seven SLCs between November 2010 and October 2012. For each requested visit, a telemedicine technician travelled to the patient's home and obtained an illness history, exam elements (e.g., lung sounds), and samples for laboratory testing. Data were then uploaded into an electronic medical record. Emergency or geriatric medicine providers reviewed the information and made diagnostic and therapeutic decisions. Descriptive statistics were used to evaluate the program using measures including telemedicine visit characteristics, satisfaction surveys of patients and informal caregivers, and surveys of the triage team about alternative care options had telemedicine been unavailable. Results: 280/298 (94.0%) requested telemedicine visits were successfully completed. Common diagnoses included respiratory (21.4%), cardiovascular (16.4%), skin (12.1%), and musculoskeletal (8.2%). 95.7% of patients received telemedicine care without requiring subsequent referral to an ED or urgent care. 93.7% of patients reported being satisfied or very satisfied with telemedicine care. Had telemedicine been unavailable, patients would have been sent to an ED (48.1%) or urgent care clinic (27.0%), or provided a later outpatient visit (24.4%). Patients' informal caregivers estimated they saved a median of 3.5 (IQR 2.5-6) hours by using telemedicine rather than an ED. Conclusion: Emergency care via telemedicine is feasible, is acceptable to older adults residing in SLCs and their caregivers, and can provide definitive care in a timely and convenient fashion without transport to an ED.
