Rapid Universal Opt-out HIV Screening in Adolescents and Adults of All Ages in an Urban Level I Trauma Center Emergency Department James T. Scribner, Jeri Rose, Benjamin Blake, Aaron Blue, Mandy Burton, and Julie Gorchynski John Peter Smith Health Network, Fort Worth, TX Background: In 2006, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) guidelines recommended rapid routine opt-out HIV screening in emergency departments for patients age 13-64. In 2009, we began a program that extended that guideline to all patients age 12 and older. To date, no ED testing program has published data specific to patients above 65 and under age 18. Objectives: To determine the feasibility and yield of rapid universal opt-out HIV screening among all patients 12 and older in an ED serving an urban population. Methods: We retrospectively reviewed the charts of all ED patients from April 1, 2009 through January 1, 2012 in this observational cross-sectional study. All individuals aged 12 and older who visited the ED in our Level I trauma center received the Centaur HIV 1/O/2 Assay, if blood was drawn for any clinical purpose. If no blood was drawn, they were offered the OraQuick rapid HIV test. Western blot (WB) was used to confirm reactive results. Ambiguous or negative WBs were further evaluated with nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT). Patients were excluded only if they had a test in the last 6 months or were under 12. Basic demographic information was analyzed by using standard descriptive statistics including frequencies and cross tabulation. Results: From April 1, 2009 through January 1, 2012, 33.7% of all ED visitors (n=65,731) accepted testing. Overall, 0.74% (n=489) of ED visitors screened positive. Of these, 164 were lost to follow-up. Confirmatory testing yielded 275 positive by WB, 36 negative, and 14 indeterminate. NAAT testing yielded 3 additional true positives from the indeterminate WBs. Overall, 0.42% of visitors were given new confirmed diagnoses of HIV. African American (RR= 1.95) and male (RR=1.61) were the most likely groups to receive a new diagnosis.Conclusion: Universal screening of all ages yields a small number of additional new HIV diagnoses (n=5), but is above the CDC recommended level of 0.1% seroprevalence.

TABREF504.text: Abstract 686 687 Lipoproteins Inhibit HMGB1 Release and Cytokine Activities Haichao Wang, Wei Li, Matthew Forrest, Jianhua Li, Shu Zhu, and Andrew E. Sama North Shore University Hospital, Manhasset, NY Background: Severe sepsis is a systemic inflammatory response syndrome, resulting from a microbial infection and associating with high mortality rate, especially in elderly patients. We previously demonstrated that a pro-inflammatory nuclear protein, HMGB1, is released from innate immune cells, such as macrophages, and mediates sepsis lethality. Objectives: In light of the increasing prevalence of lipoprotein imbalances in the aging population and involvement of lipoproteins in inflammatory diseases, we investigated the effects of high density lipoprotein (HDL) and low density lipoprotein (LDL) on the release and cytokine activity of HMGB1 in vitro. Methods: Murine macrophage-like RAW 264.7 cells were stimulated with bacterial endotoxin (lipopolysaccharide, LPS, 500 ng/ml), recombinant HMGB1 (2.0 lg/ml) in the absence or presence of HDL (10-200 lg/ml), or LDL (10-200 lg/ml) for 16 hours. The levels of HMGB1 and other cytokines/chemokines in the culture medium were determined by Western blotting or cytokine antibody arrays. Results: Both HDL and LDL dose-dependently attenuated LPSinduced HMGB1 release, with a >95% suppression by lipoproteins at concentrations as low as 50 lg/ml. Similarly, both HDL and LDL effectively inhibited HMGB1-induced release of IL-6 and several chemokines (e.g., MCP-1, RANTES, and CXCL16), indicating that the common component of these lipoprotein complexes (i.e. phospholipids) PC), a major phospholipid in both HDL and LDL, dose-dependently inhibited LPS-induced HMGB1 release, with a complete abrogation at concentrations as low as 50 µg/ml. Conclusion: PC is partly responsible for the anti-inflammatory effect of lipoproteins in vitro, which may confer protection by partly attenuating HMGB1 release and cytokine activities. Diagnostic Characteristics of a Clinical Screening Tool in Combination with POCT Lactates in ED Patients with Suspected Sepsis Adam J. Singer, Maria B. Taylor, Anna T. Domingo, Saad Ghazipura, Adam Khorasanchi, and Henry C. Thode Jr. Stony Brook University, Stony Brook, NY Background: Early identification of sepsis and initiation of goaldirected therapy saves lives. However, the diagnosis of sepsis may be delayed in patients with cryptic shock. Clinical screening tools and lactate levels may help identify patients with cryptic shock.

TABREF505.text: Complaints of Patients TestingPositive in a Universal HIV Screening Program Kurt Weber, Philip Giordano, Michael Sanders, and Sandra Sawyer orlando regional medical center, Orlando, FL Background: Current CDC recommendations call for universal HIV screening in emergency departments where seroprevelance is >0.1%. However, recent studies suggest targeted HIV screening outperforms nontargeted strategies and should be employed given the limited resources available to health care systems. Chief complaints could be one piece of a targeted strategy if a positive diagnosis is found in a limited set of complaints.Objectives: Our objective is to describe the scope of chief complaints of ED patients testing positive for HIV and determine their utility for a targeted HIV screening program.Methods: Our study is a retrospective cohort design set in an urban, tertiary care emergency department that has offered free universal HIV screening through a state-funded grant since May 2008. The study population consists of patients identified through a computerized database who tested positive over the duration of the grant. Data including chief complaint, age, and sex were abstracted by chart review by two investigators. Two separate investigators blinded to HIV test result determined whether a chief complaint could be associated with an HIV diagnosis. Descriptive statistics were used to describe the study population.Results: A total of 5086 tests were performed with 176 testing positive, for an overall prevalence of 3.4%. The age range of positives was 18-68 with a mean age of 46. Males accounted for 126 cases (39%).Forty-two distinct chief complaints were identified. The most common were cough (19), dyspnea (17), abscess (10), abdominal pain(9), and fatigue(8). Overall 12 (28%) separate chief complaints in 35 (20%) patients were considered to be unrelated to HIV infection.Conclusion: Patients who ultimately test positive for HIV in a universal screening setting present with a wide variety of chief complaints. As many as 20% of these patients have chief complaints unlikely to be related to HIV infection. Our data suggest a targeted HIV screening process that incorporates chief complaint would potentially miss a critical number of asymptomatic HIV infections. St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital Center, New York, NY; 2 Jacobi Medical Center, Bronx, NY; 3 New York State Department of Health AIDS Institute, New York, NY. Background: In 2010, NY State passed legislation mandating that all emergency departments (EDs) offer HIV testing to persons 13-64 presenting for care. This positions NY as the only state with a law requiring ED HIV testing. Objectives: To evaluate statewide implementation of this ED testing requirement and determine if differences exist based on HIV prevalence or site-specific designated AIDS centers (DACs). To evaluate policies for linkage to care in positive patients. Methods: An electronic survey was administered to all NY ED directors excluding VA hospitals. Investigators developed survey questions related to all provisions of the legislation and linkage to care. Face validity was tested by ED and HIV physicians. Basic descriptive statistics were used for analysis. Results: The response rate was 96% (183/191). All respondents were aware of the testing law. Of the 180 respondents who answered the question about testing, 86% reported offering HIV testing in their EDs. All EDs not currently offering HIV testing reported plans to initiate it. EDs in high-prevalence areas and state DACs were more likely to offer HIV testing. Although the law eliminated the requirement for separate written consent for an HIV test, most facilities (107/159, 67%) still used this technique. Although allowed by the law, only 11% incorporated HIV testing language into the general treatment consent and 19% used verbal consent for rapid tests. The HIV testing offer was primarily performed by clinicians but also included clerical staff, public health advocates, social workers, and through written testing information. Most EDs used rapid testing (67%) including both oral point-of-care ED testing and rapid laboratory testing. Only 62% of EDs provided HIV test results to patients while still in the ED. Most EDs (90%) had a linkage to care protocol in place; however, only 33% of those confirm successful linkage. Conclusion: We provide the first report of statewide ED HIV testing practices in NY since the passage of a mandatory testing law. With 96% of EDs reporting, most offer HIV testing but to varying degrees. Challenges to full implementation still exist as many EDs are not delivering results to patients while still in the ED. Linkage to care plans for patients testing preliminary positive are in place but few EDs follow up with patients to determine if linkage has occurred. Increased Endotoxin Activity is Associated with Clinical Deterioration in Moderate Severity Emergency Department Sepsis Patients: A Pilot Study Ryan Arnold, Christa Schorr, Stephen Trzeciak, and R. Phil Dellinger Cooper University Hospital, Camden, NJ Background: High levels of endotoxin activity are associated with increased mortality in ICU patients.Objectives: To assess endotoxin activity in emergency department (ED) patients with normotensive sepsis to determine the ability of the endotoxin activity assay (EAA) measurement and its change over 24 hours to predict progressive organ dysfunction.Methods: Design: Prospective observational study. Setting: A singlecenter prospective observational study in an urban, academic medical center. Participants: Adult ED patients with suspected infection admitted to a medical floor and receiving IV antibiotics with either elevated lactate (2.0-3.9 mM) or transient hypotension (sBP <90 mmHg). EAA was measured at enrollment and again at 24 hours and results were divided based on benchmark cutoffs for "low" (1 point, mechanical ventilation or vasopressor utilization) within 72 hours of admission or in-hospital mortality.Results: We enrolled 57 patients over a 12-month period. The primary outcome was met in 63% of the cohort and 33% were transferred to the ICU from their initial medical floor admissions.Patients with the outcome of increased organ failure had no difference in initial lactate, age, MAP, or exposure to hypotension. Patients meeting primary outcome had a higher ICU transfer rate (42% vs 19%, p=0.15) and increased ICU (2 vs 0) and hospital lengths of stay (13 vs 8).Outcome patients had similar endotoxin levels at enrollment compared to those not meeting outcome (0.61 vs 0.51, p=0.075) with increased levels at 24 hours (0.73 vs. 0.47, p=0.005). An increased incidence of the primary outcome was seen with each category increase in EAA. An increasing endotoxin level over 24 hours had a 71% specificity and 72% PPV in predicting the primary outcome.Conclusion: Within this sepsis cohort, physiologic data in the ED were unable to differentiate those with progressive organ dysfunction over 72 hours, while endotoxin levels were higher at 24 hours. A high or increasing EAA as a predictor of progressive organ dysfunction can supplement clinical decision-making to aid clinicians in identifying highrisk patients from this homogeneous sepsis population.Background: Staphylococcus aureus infection is responsible for a variety of clinical disease presentations. While culture techniques are the gold standard for detection of S. aureus in clinical samples the time required for results of these tests mean they have no direct effect on the emergency department management of patients. The development of a cost-effective rapid point-of-care diagnostic test could reduce the use of broad spectrum antibiotics for these infections and improve clinical outcomes. Previously our group performed mass spectrometry on the culture supernatants of 14 S. aureus strains and identified eight proteins targets with conserved C-terminal peptide sequences against which Cterminal antibodies (CTAbs) were raised. CTAbs are antibodies targeted against a five amino acid polypeptide representing the C-terminus of a protein of interest. They are produced by conjugating the polypeptide to a carrier protein and then immunizing an animal against this antigen. It has been shown that CTAbs are highly sensitive and specific for a target protein. S. aureus secretes protein A which binds mammalian IgG antibodies non-specifically. To circumvent this, CTAbs against S. aureus target proteins were raised in chickens, rather than rodents, as chicken IgY does not interact non-specifically with protein A.Objectives: The main goal of this study was to facilitate the validation of such a diagnostic panel of CTAbs for the detection of S. aureus from clinical samples by developing a parallel panel of recombinant proteins representing the S. aureus diagnostic targets.Methods: Target S. aureus genes were amplified by PCR and cloned into Escherichia coli pET19b vector. Orientation of gene inserts and plasmid C-terminal sequence was verified by sequencing. Plasmid constructs were transferred to E. coli expression hosts and protein expression was induced with 1M IPTG. Western blot was used to determine the reactivity of the CTAbs with the recombinant proteins.Results: During this study all eight target proteins were produced recombinantly in E. coli. The reactivity of CTAbs against six out of eight recombinant protein targets was confirmed.

TABREF506.text: Abstract 692: CTAb reactivity with recombinant proteins produced Target S. aureus protein Conclusion: These six antibodies could potentially make a rapid diagnostic panel for detecting S. aureus directly from clinical samples. Further work is needed to validate the ability of CTAbs to detect S. aureus in clinical samples. Defining the Impact of Delayed Antibiotic Administration Using a Comprehensive Electronic Health Record Screen to Identify Severe Sepsis Ryan Arnold, R. Phil Dellinger, and Steven M. Hollenberg Cooper University Hospital, Camden, NJ Background: The true effectiveness of early antibiotic administration relative to the clinical identification of sepsis in a realworld setting is unknown. Previous studies described the effect of antibiotic timing within an isolated septic shock cohort. A novel electronic health record (EHR) screening tool, Clinical Vigilance TM for Sepsis, is able to identify the presence of severe sepsis across a consecutive patient population.

TABREF507.text: Figure -Abstract 693694 Incidence of Emergency Department Visits Due to Pneumonia in the United States, 2006-2009: Findings from the Nationwide Emergency Department Sample Wesley H. Self, Carlos G. Grijalva, Yuwei Zhu, Candace D. McNaughton, Tyler W. Barrett, Sean P. Collins, Alan B. Storrow, and Marie R. Griffin Vanderbilt University Medical Center, Nashville, TNBackground: A detailed understanding of pneumonia incidence in the emergency department (ED) will be essential for evaluating the effect of the new 13-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV-13) on pneumonia-related health care encounters.

TABREF508.text: Figure -Abstract 694 695 Demographic and Treatment Patterns for Infections in Ambulatory Settings in the United States, 2009 Larissa May, Peter M. Mullins, and Jesse M. Pines George Washington University, Washington, DC Background: Acute ambulatory infections can be treated in many settings, including hospital-based emergency departments (ED) and outpatient clinics. Several factors may influence patient choice in selecting care settings. Additionally, the treatment of ambulatory infections may differ across settings.Objectives: To examine treatment and demographic patterns for urinary tract infections (UTIs), upper respiratory infections (URI), and skin and soft tissue infections in EDs and outpatient clinics.Methods: This study used nationally representative samples from the National Hospital Ambulatory Care Survey (NHAMCS) and National Ambulatory Care Survey (NAMCS) from 2009 for EDs and outpatient clinics, respectively. Patient visits age ! 18 with a primary diagnosis of UTI, URI, or SSTI were included. Demographic patterns, resource utilization, and management characteristics were tabulated using complex survey weights and compared across settings using a weighted chi-square analysis. Commonly used medications were assessed by tabulating the 20 most common drugs prescribed for each diagnosis and classifying them by drug class.Results: In 2009, there were 8.2 million ambulatory visits for UTI, 34.4 million visits for URI, and 7.6 million visits for SSTI in the U.S. Of those, 23% of UTI, 12% of URI, and 30% of SSTI visits were seen in EDs. Across the three groups, ED patients were more likely to be younger, black, and have Medicaid or no insurance. ED patients received more blood tests (56% versus 18% for UTI, 24% versus 16% for URI, and 25% versus 22% for SSTI) and imaging studies (34% versus 15% for UTI, 31% versus 10% for URI, and 18% versus 7% for SSTI). ED patients were more likely to receive pain medications; over 25% of URI and SSTI visits received narcotics. In both settings, over 50% of URI patients received antibiotics and over 40% of UTI visits received broad-spectrum fluoroquinolones. Conclusion: The patient populations and treatment of acute ambulatory infections differ across care settings. Patient factors analyzed suggest access to care and differences in pain acuity may explain differences in patient choice of care setting. The observed antibiotic use suggests the possible need for better stewardship in both ED and outpatient clinics in the U.S. The Evaluation of Febrile Infants Less Than One year of Age Between Emergency Medicine Physicians and Pediatric Emergency Medicine Physicians Antonio Muniz Dallas Regional Medical Center, Mesquite, TX Background: Management of febrile infants less than 1 month of age can vary depending on the physician's training, experience and, confidence.Objectives: The study hypothesis is that physicians trained in emergency medicine (EM) order more diagnostic tests than physicians with pediatric emergency medicine (PEM) training.Methods: Prospective study in a university pediatric emergency department. All consecutive infants less than 1 month of age with fever (> 38°C) without a definite source for the infection were included. Infants were treated by PEM physicians from 8:00 am -1:00 am and by EM physicians from 1:00 am-5:00 pm. Data were analyzed using Stata 11 with continuous variables expressed as means, while categorical variables were summarized as frequencies of occurrence and assessed for statistical significance using chi-square test or Fisher's exact test.Results: Of 654 infants, 564 (86.2%) were seen by PEM physicians, and 90 (13.7%) by EM physicians. The median age in the PEM group was 19.3 AE 17.7 days-old (95% CI 18.2, 20.4), and in the EM group 19.2 AE 8.8 days-old (95% CI 15.9, 22.4). There were no significant differences between groups in their demographic data, vital signs, or symptoms. The number admitted in the PEM group was 516 (91.4%) which was less than the EM group, 90 (100%) (p < 0.05). The laboratory evaluation in the PEM group included a CBC 528 (93.6%), urinalysis and culture 528 (93.6%), blood culture 528 (93.6%), chest radiograph 228 (40.4%), and CSF fluid analysis 516 (91.4%). In the EM group all infants had a CBC, urinalysis, urine culture, blood culture, and CSF fluid analysis performed. There were 75 (83%) chest radiograph performed. There were more chest radiographs performed in the EM group (p < 0.05), while all other tests were similar.Conclusion: There are still some differences in the management of young febrile infants. EM-trained physicians are loyal to the practice guidelines and order more CXRs than the PEM-trained physicians.Background: On October 2, 2012, the Federal Drug Administration and the Centers for Disease Control began recommending that providers emergently contact patients exposed to fungus-contaminated epidural steroid injections (ESI).Objectives: We characterize the findings in a large cohort of patients presenting to the emergency department (ED) after being informed of an exposure to fungus-contaminated ESI.Methods: All ED patients presenting during a 21-day period with a chief complaint of exposure to fungus-contaminated ESI were assessed for symptoms of systemic illness, neurological symptoms, headache, neck pain, or pain at the site of injection. Patients with these symptoms or signs including neurological deficit or meningeal findings were advised to undergo lumbar puncture (LP) and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis. CSF samples were analyzed in accordance with a standardized assessment protocol specific to this ESI fungus-exposure event. Patient data reviewed included patient demographics, complete blood cell counts, CSF findings, ED disposition, and patient outcomes. Descriptive statistics were used to summarize data.Results: Approximately 650 patients were contacted by two local facilities in our region. These contacts provoked 156 ED encounters (23%), with 58 patients presenting in the first three days of the notification period. Demographic findings included a mean age of 56 years (range: 23-89), with 94 women and 62 men. 154 patients underwent complete ED evaluations, with one left without being seen, and one left before treatment complete. Lumbar puncture was performed on 122 patients (79%). ED mean CSF findings included: white blood cell count 1121, absolute neutrophil count 844, glucose 47, and protein 132. Disposition included 32 patients (21%) admitted for further evaluation and treatment, with 18 (12%) receiving a discharge diagnosis of fungal meningitis. There were no deaths in the patient cohort. Fifteen patients (10%) returned to the ED for further evaluation including post-LP headache, and symptoms believed to be related to ESI fungal exposure.Conclusion: The recent fungus-contaminated ESI event has been a unique event in the history of emergency medicine and infectious disease. The event has included a large number of patients undergoing ED LP with a relatively large number of fungal meningitis diagnoses. Antigen-Specific Influenza Antibody Responses in Acute Respiratory Tract Infections and its Relation to Influenza Infection and Disease Course John P. Haran, Huaiqing Chen, and Shan Lu University of Massachusetts Medical School, Worcester, MA Background: There are differences in influenza antibody levels produced during infection. The extent to which influenza-specific antibody titers protect against influenza infection in adult humans and how it affects clinical course is not known. Objectives: To characterize the different influenza-specific antibody titers among influenza-infected and non-infected individuals.Methods: We enrolled adults who presented to an urban academic ED from October through March during the 2008-2011 influenza seasons. Patient's nasal aspirates were testing by viral culture, and peripheral blood for hemagglutination inhibition assay against eight pseudotype viruses (psv) expressing H1 antigens that represent over 30 years of influenza viruses. Student's t-test was used to analyze antibody titers of flu-positive versus flu-negative patients. Simple regression assessed the relation between duration of symptoms and the log of the antibody level for each antigen type. Pearson's product-moment coefficient was used.Results: There were 139 total patients, 57 with influenza infection and 82 negative for influenza infection. Patients with an influenza infection had a marked lower antibody titer averaged over all eight pseudotype viruses with a titer of 287.5 compared to those with a non-influenza illness, at 640.2 (p=0.00018). Reported as the reciprocal of the highest dilution that can still produce complete hemagglutination. Influenza-infected patients who were discharged from the ED had significantly lower antibody titers compared to those admitted to the hospital among psv1995.

TABREF509.text: 699BloodCulture Use and Appropriateness in US EDs, 2002-2010 Leah S. Honigman 1 , and Jeremiah D. Schuur 2 Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, Boston, MA; 2 Brigham and Women's Hospital, Boston, MA Background: Blood cultures (BCs) are often obtained in the ED for patients with suspected bacteremia. While there is expert consensus that BCs are indicated for conditions such as sepsis and BCs are recommended by the Surviving Sepsis Campaign, routine BC use among ED patients has limited clinical utility. In lower-risk conditions, BCs rarely change clinical management, have a low sensitivity for bacteremia, and false positives are costly. Objectives: To describe use and appropriateness of BC for adult ED visits. We hypothesized that use of BC has 1) increased among ED visits with a diagnosis of sepsis and 2) decreased among ED visits discharged with a low-risk diagnosis. Methods: We performed a retrospective, cross-sectional analysis of the 2002-2010 National Hospital Ambulatory Medical Care Survey (NHAMCS) of all ED visits for patients age ! 18 who had BCs drawn. NHAMCS includes data from approximately 36,000 ED visits per year, weighted to represent a national sample. BC use was recorded as a specific field except in 2005-6, which were excluded. We analyzed the proportion of ED visits where BCs were drawn among 1) those admitted with sepsis and 2) lower-risk ED visits, defined as presenting from home and discharged from the ED with a diagnosis of urinary tract infection, cellulitis, pneumonia, COPD, or other respiratory disease. We compared average BC use in 2002-4 to 2007-10 using chisquare and logistic regression to test for trend from 2007-10 (SAS 9.3); p<0.05 was significant. Results: From 2002-4, BCs were drawn for an average of 2.4M ED visits per year and from 2007-10 an average of 4.1M visits per year. See table for BC use by disposition and subgroup, see figure for annual BC use. The proportion of ED visits with BCs drawn increased by 1.3% (p<0.0001) from 2002-4 to 2007-10. The proportion of visits with sepsis and BCs did not increase (p=0.7). Among low-risk visits, the proportion with BCs increased by 1.1% (p=0.003). There was no significant annual change from 2007-2010 for BC use overall or for the two subgroups.

TABREF510.text: Abstract 699: Proportion of adult ED visits with blood cultures, 2002-2010 Conclusion: The use of BC in EDs is rising and appropriateness does not appear to be improving. The relatively low rate of BC and lack of change in patients with sepsis deserves further research as it may represent a gap in quality of care or a problem with the NHAMCS data collection. The increase among patients who are lowrisk to develop bacteremia represents an inappropriate and costly use of BC. Are High-Risk Patients More Likely to Say Yes to an Human Immunodeficiency Virus Test? An Evaluation of Emergency Department Patients in a Rapid Testing Program Rishi Vohra, Daniel Egan, Meghan Ahearn, Eliot Wall, and Dan Wiener St. Luke's-Roosevelt, New York, NY Background: Over 1.1 million people in the US have HIV and 200,000 are unaware of their status. Since 2010 NY State has mandated that EDs offer HIV tests to all patients 13-64. It is unclear what prompts a person to accept or decline a test in our population. Objectives: To compare the demographics of patients who accept and decline HIV tests and to determine if differences in risk factors prompt acceptance of testing. To determine as a measure of quality improvement whether patients were truly offered a test by the triage nurse when designated as declining a test by the nurse. Methods: We prospectively enrolled a convenience sample of English and Spanish speaking patients 18 and older in two urban NYC EDs. Trained research associates administered surveys to patients based on their desire for an HIV test as designated by the triage nurse. Investigators used basic descriptive statistics and a Student's t-test for comparisons. Results: 2,312 total participants were enrolled: 1,153 accepted an HIV test and 1,159 declined. 1,805 patients were initially identified as declining an HIV test by the triage nurse; however, when asked directly, 646/1805 (36%) reported they were not actually asked by the nurse and 84 of these requested a test from the research assistant (13%). Patients in the youngest age category (18-29) were more likely to accept testing (49.3% v. 39.7%, p<0.001). Those who accepted were more likely to be uninsured (16.2% v. 11.1%, p<0.001) and less likely to have private insurance (31.6% v. 39.1%, p<0.001). Both groups identified having similar sexual practices(Table 1). Most risk factors were similar when comparing the two groups, although more patients who accepted testing reported unprotected sex, getting paid for sex, multiple sex partners, and sex while using drugs or alcohol (Table 2). Although 50.1% in the accepted study and 31.3% in the declined study reported at least one risk factor (p<0.001) only 14.7% and 7.4% (p<0.001) acknowledged themselves "at risk" for HIV.

TABREF511.text: Abstract 700: Sexual PracticesBackground: In contrast to relatively common enteroviral (EnV) meningitis, early recognition of herpes simplex (HSV) meningitis is considered essential, as early treatment can reduce mortality by 20-30% . Currently there is no objective way to promptly differentiate benign EnV from the potentially life-threatening HSV.Objectives: Identify clinical features and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) results that differentiate EnV from HSV meningitis.Methods: A historical cohort study was conducted from January 2005 to December 2011, enrolling patients over 3 months of age with HSV or EnV polymerase chain reaction (PCR) positive CSF specimens, identified at our regional virology laboratory. Patients without PCR results who had other CSF findings and neuroimaging consistent with viral meningitis and a final diagnosis of meningitis were included. Clinical and laboratory data were obtained from electronic records and paper charts, including emergency department triage assessments, records of treatment, and discharge summaries. Descriptive and univariate statistical analyses were conducted for clinical features and CSF findings.Results: 166 consecutive patients were enrolled in the study, 40 HSV and 126 EnV cases. The table summarizes univariate results between groups. A significant difference between HSV and EnV patients was found in mean age [40.4 vs 31.3, p=0.005], history of seizure [21.1 vs 1.6%, p=<0.001], history of altered mental status [46.2 vs 3.2%, p=<0.001] and neurological deficit on physical exam [44.7 vs 3.9%, p=<0.001]. CSF findings demonstrated no significant difference in white blood cell counts [331.1 x 10 6 vs 279.2 x 10 6 /L, p =0.5]; however, neutrophil differential counts were significantly lower in HSV cases [7.2 vs 23.7%, p=<0.001]; and lymphocyte counts (79.7 vs 61.6%, p=<0.001] and protein levels [1.0 vs 0.7 g/L, p=0.03] were significantly higher. Subgroup analyses of PCR confirmed (N=29 vs 19) and immunocompetent confirmed cases (N=23 vs 19) revealed consistent findings.Conclusion: Patients with HSV meningitis were more likely than EnV meningitis to be older; present with seizure, altered mental status and neurological deficits; have lower CSF neutrophil counts and higher CSF lymphocyte and protein levels. HSV treatment should be strongly considered in patients with one or more of these features, while awaiting definitive PCR results.

TABREF512.text: Abstract 701Background: Emergency departments (EDs) are developing varied, innovative strategies to adapt HIV testing into routine practice since the 2006 CDC HIV testing recommendations. One approach, kioskfacilitated self-testing, has been shown to be highly accurate and generally well-accepted by patients.

TABREF513.text: 703Surgical and AntimicrobialTreatment of Skin Infections in the Age of CA-MRSA Daniel J. Pallin, and Jeremiah D. Schuur Brigham and Women's Hospital, Boston, MA Background: Evidence and guidelines suggest that most abscesses do not require antibiotics, and that most cases of cellulitis can be treated without agents effective against CA-MRSA. In 2007, the National Hospital Ambulatory Medical Care Survey (NHAMCS) added a record of whether I&D was performed at each ED visit, presenting an opportunity for evaluation of care. Objectives: Evaluate medical and surgical care of skin infections at US ED visits. Propose quality measures, based on Infectious Diseases Society of America Guidelines. Evaluate measure adherence, stratifying by region.

TABREF514.text: 704LoadingDoses of Vancomycin in the Emergency Department: Is It Safe? Julie Laughner 1 , Jamie Rosini 1 , Brian Levine 1 , John Reinhardt 1 , Hannah Lawry 1 , Mia Papas 2 , Cynthia Hoon 1 , and Neil Jasani 1 1 Christiana Care, Newark, DE; 2 University of Delaware, Newark, DE Background: Although the Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA) has proposed vancomycin loading doses of 25-30 mg/kg for the rapid attainment of therapeutic concentrations, the safety and efficacy of these regimens have not been prospectively studied. Higher-dose vancomycin regimens and prolonged vancomycin administration has been associated with nephrotoxicity and other side effects. Objectives: To determine if patients have increased rates of nephrotoxicity or other adverse events when utilizing IDSArecommended loading doses of vancomycin.

TABREF515.text: Abstract 703: Medical and Surgical Management of Skin Infection Visits to US EDs (Excluding Follow-up Visits) Results: Ninety-nine patients were enrolled. Results are noted in the table. One patient in the 30 mg/kg group was presumed to have red man syndrome as his symptoms resolved with a decrease in infusion rate. No patients required dialysis. No patients reported hearing deficits or were readmitted to the hospital with nephrotoxicity up to one month from enrollment date.Conclusion: There are no differences in adverse events when comparing a loading dose of 30 mg/kg versus an initial dose of 15 mg/ kg of vancomycin in patients with normal renal function.

TABREF516.text: Abstract 704: Relationship of dose to adverse events Background: Guideline antibiotic treatment of health careassociated pneumonia (HCAP) differs from other infection but adherence remains low.

TABREF517.text: to Preventing New HIV Infections in a High-Risk Urban Population Meghan Ahearn, Daniel Egan, Rishi Vohra, Eliot Wall, and Dan Wiener St. Luke's-Roosevelt, New York, NY Background: Over 1.1 million people in the US have HIV, with nearly 120,000 cases in NYC. Consistently each year, 50,000 new infections occur. Previous studies on ED HIV testing have focused on methodology, linkage to care, and testing barriers. Fewer have investigated public health questions about HIV, its transmission, and primary care access.Objectives: To assess ED patients' knowledge and understanding of HIV and risks for contracting the virus. To assess ED patients' primary care physician (PCP) access and whether they receive HIV tests at PCP visits.Methods: We prospectively enrolled English-and Spanish-speaking patients over the age of 18 in two NYC EDs. Triage nurses offered all patients HIV testing. Two surveys were administered: one for those who agreed to testing, and one for those who declined. Surveys included demographic information, reasons for accepting or declining, knowledge of HIV, self-reported high-risk behaviors, and PCP information. Descriptive statistics and Student's t-tests were used for analysis.Results: 2,312 participants were enrolled: 1,153 in the accepted study (A) and 1,159 in the declined study (D). Demographics were similar between the two groups: the majority were heterosexual, under the age of 39, female, and black or Hispanic. 86.3% in A and 92.6% in D said they were not at risk for HIV (p<0.05). Only 61.1% in A and 72.4% in D recognized that HIV is treatable (p<0.001). 16.7% and 16.5% (p=0.70), respectively, believed HIV can be transmitted through kissing. The majority understood that unsafe sex is a means of transmission (92.3% and 97.0 %, p<0.001). 64.9% in A and 75.6% in D have PCPs (p<0.001), but only 39.4% in A and 43.1% in D were offered testing at their last PCP visit (p=0.88). Conclusion: Demographics and responses to public health questions were similar between the two populations. The results highlight significant knowledge gaps about HIV and its treatment and transmission in an urban area with a very high prevalence of HIV. Most have PCPs, but only a minority were offered testing at their last PCP visit. Understanding the knowledge limitations of this high-risk population will facilitate better allocation of public health resources and efforts to prevent new infections. Viral Respiratory Detections in Children and Adults with Community-acquired Pneumonia Compared with Asymptomatic Controls: Evaluating the Role of Viral Pathogens in Pneumonia Wesley H. Self 1 , Derek J. Williams 1 , Kathryn M. Edwards 1 , Yuwei Zhu 1 , James D. Chappell 1 , Christopher Trabue 2 , Eileen Schneider 3 , Anna M. Bramley 3 , Seema Jain 3 , Carlos G. Grijalva 1 1 Vanderbilt University Medical Center, Nashville, TN; 2 Baptist Hospital, Nashville, TN; 3 Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Atlanta, GA Background: Viruses are often detected in upper respiratory specimens of patients with community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) but determining their etiologic significance is challenging. Objectives: To quantify the contribution of viruses to CAP by comparing their prevalence detected by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) in naso/oropharyngeal (NP/OP) swabs between CAP cases and asymptomatic controls. Methods: In the CDC Etiology of Pneumonia in the Community Study (EPIC), we enrolled children (<18 years old) and adults hospitalized with clinical and radiographic CAP (cases) in three hospitals in Nashville, TN from Jan. 2010 -June 2012. We also enrolled a convenience sample of asymptomatic controls that included children enrolled from Mar. 2011 -June 2012 and adults enrolled from Nov. 2011 -June 2012. NP/OP specimens were tested with PCR for respiratory viruses. Analyses were conducted separately for children and adults, and limited to the time of concurrent case/control enrollment. The percentage of cases [a] and controls [b] positive for each virus was calculated. Attributable fraction [AF] --the estimated proportion of cases positive for a specific virus for which that virus was responsible for disease --was calculated as: (a -b)/a. The percentage of all CAP cases with disease attributable to each virus was calculated as: a x AF. Results: Enrollment included 693 children (404 cases, 289 controls) and 426 adults (187 cases, 239 controls). In children, ! 1 virus was detected in 65.8% of cases and 22.5% of controls, and in adults, 23.5% of cases and 2.1% of controls. The table shows percentages of cases with disease attributable to each virus. For example, human rhinovirus (hRV) was commonly detected in both case and control children, resulting in an AF of 0.3 and 7.4% of cases with CAP attributable to hRV. Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) and human metapneumovirus (hMPV) were attributable to 22.5% and 11.8% of child cases, respectively. Among adults, detection was rare in controls for all viruses; hRV and hMPV had the greatest number of attributable cases with 9.2% and 3.9%, respectively. Influenza was uncommon among cases and never detected in controls; therefore, when present in cases, influenza was always attributable to CAP. Conclusion: After accounting for asymptomatic detections, RSV, hMPV, and hRV in children and hRV and hMPV in adults were the viruses most commonly attributable to CAP. Trends in Emergency Department Abscess Care Melanie K. Prusakowski, and Damon R. Kuehl Carilion Clinic, Roanoke, VA Background: Skin and soft tissue infections (SSTI) are a major cause of ED visits. Abscess is a distinct SSTI requiring incision and drainage (I&D). Previous national surveys combined all SSTI to estimate abscesseseand evaluate their management by EM providers. It remains unclear how many SSTI require I&D or how providers are currently using antibiotics. Studies have shown antibiotics may not be needed for care of abscess after I&D but are likely indicated for other SSTI. Objectives: We examined 4 years of National Hospital Ambulatory Medical Care Survey (NHAMCS) data to estimate the number of current SSTI and abscesses requiring I&D and determine antibiotic use in their management. We hypothesized antibiotic rates are declining in response to evidence that antibiotics are unnecessary for most SSTI requiring I&D. Methods: NHAMCS is a national probability sample of visits to US emergency departments (ED). ED patients from 2007-2010 with diagnosis codes for cutaneous abscess and skin or soft tissue infection were included. Starting in 2007, NHAMCS included a procedure code for I&D. Patients with SSTI and I&D were determined. Antibiotics given in the ED or at discharge were obtained for all discharged patients with SSTI and I&D. Total patients with SSTI, percent receiving I&D, and the percents receiving one or more antibiotics were determined. Prescribed antibiotics were characterized and classified based on efficacy to MRSA. Results: ED visits for SSTI increased from 3.55M (95% CI 3.24-3.86) in 2007 to 4.21M (95% CI 3.89-4.55M) in 2010. Patients with SSTI receiving I&D rose from 736k (95% CI 602k-869k) to 1.48M (95% CI 1.30-1.65M). SSTI requiring I&D comprised a mean of 32.2% of SSTI visits over the 4 years. In 2007, 85.1% (95 CI 82.6-87.7) of patients were given antibiotics in the ED or at discharge after I&D, and the percentage did not change over 4 years (85.5% in 2010, 95% CI 82.5-88.5). In 2010, 15.5% (95 CI 12.1-18.7) of patients received two or more antibiotic prescriptions. The most commonly prescribed antibiotic was TMP/SMX (mean 49.1%), followed by cephalexin (17.5%) and clindamycin (15.1%). Conclusion: ED visits for SSTI continues to rise. Despite evidence against antibiotics in SSTI requiring I&D, antibiotic use is high and has not declined. Many patients receive multiple antibiotics, including drugs with no efficacy to MRSA. Organ Dysfunction in Survivors of Septic Shock Treated with Early Quantitative Resuscitation Sarah A. Sterling, Michael A. Puskarich, and Alan E. Jones University of Mississippi Medical Center, Jackson, MS Background: Previous research has shown early quantitative resuscitation improves mortality. However, little is known about its ability to mitigate organ dysfunction among those who survive hospitalization.

TABREF518.text: Abstract 707: Attributable fractions and percent of CAP cases attributable to each virus among children and adults hospitalization between patients who received early quantitative resuscitation versus non-protocolized care. Background: In 2009 the Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA) published a vancomycin therapeutic guideline consensus statement. Despite little evidence, loading doses of 25-30 mg/kg for critically ill patients are recommended to facilitate rapid attainment of target vancomycin levels (15-20 mg/L).Objectives: Determine if a higher proportion of patients administered a loading dose of 30 mg/kg reach target trough levels when compared to a traditional dose of 15 mg/kg.

TABREF519.text: Abstract 710: Percentage of patients with troughs above the threshold 711 A Consensus-Based Gold Standard for Who Needs a Trauma Center E. Brooke Lerner 1 , Brian Willenbring 1 , Karen Brasel 1 , Charles E. Cady 1 , M. Riccardo Colella 1 , Arthur Cooper 2 , Jeremy T. Cushman 3 , David M. Gourlay 1 , Gregory J. Jurkovich 4 , Craig D. Newgard 5 , Ronald G. Pirrallo 1 , Jeffrey P. Salomone 6 , Scott M. Sasser 6 , Manish N. Shah 3 , Robert Swor 7 , and Stewart C. Wang 8 1 Medical College of Wisconsin Affiliated Hospitals, Milwaukee, WI; 2 Columbia University Medical Center Affiliation at Harlem Hospital, New York, NY; 3 University of Rochester, Rochester, NY; 4 Denver Health Medical Center, Denver, CO; 5 Oregon Health & Science University, Portland, OR; 6 Emory University School of Medicine, Atlanta, GA; 7 William Beaumont Hospital, Royal Oak, MI; 8 University of Michigan Health Systems, Ann Arbor, MI Background: In civilian trauma care, field triage is the process applied by prehospital care providers to identify patients who have severe injuries and need the resources of a trauma center. Studies of the efficacy of field triage have used various measures to define trauma center need as no "gold-standard" exists, making cross-study comparisons difficult. Objectives: To develop a consensus-based functional gold-standard definition of trauma center need. Methods: Local and national experts were recruited for participation. Blinded key informant interviews were conducted in order of availability until no new themes emerged. Themes identified during the interviews were used to develop a Modified Delphi survey, which was electronically delivered via Survey Monkey. The trauma center need criteria were refined iteratively based on participant responses. Participants completed additional surveys until there was at least 80% agreement for each criterion.

TABREF520.text: 712Comparisonof a Clinical Decision Rule Versus Usual Care to Risk-Stratify Children for Intra-abdominal Injury after Blunt Abdominal Trauma: A Cost-Effectiveness Analysis Daniel K. Nishijima, Zhuo Yang, John A. Clark, Nathan Kuppermann, James F. Holmes, and Joy A. Melnikow University of California, Davis, Sacramento, CA Background: A clinical decision rule (CDR) was developed to identify pediatric patients with blunt abdominal trauma (BAT) at very low risk for an intra-abdominal injury that would require intervention (IAI). Potential benefits of a CDR include decreased abdominal CT utilization and health care costs. Objectives: The objective of this study was to model the costeffectiveness of the CDR compared to usual care for pediatric patients with BAT. We hypothesize that compared to usual care, implementation of the CDR would project lower health care system costs and lower CT utilization. Methods: We constructed a cost-effectiveness decision analytic model comparing the costs and outcomes of implementation of the CDR versus usual care in pediatric patients with BAT. Analyses were performed from the perspective of the health care system. Probabilities were derived from a multi-site cohort study of children with BAT; costs were estimated based on study coordinating site costs. Outcome measures include missed IAI, number of abdominal CT scans, total costs, and incremental cost-effectiveness ratios. Sensitivity analyses were conducted varying imputed probabilities, costs, and scenarios. Results: Using a hypothetical cohort of 1,000 pediatric patients with BAT, the base case model projected that the implementation of the CDR would result in 0.47 additional missed IAI, a total cost savings of $51,301, and 100 fewer abdominal CT scans compared to usual care. The usual care strategy would cost $110,811 to prevent missing one additional IAI. Findings were robust under multiple sensitivity analyses. Conclusion: Compared to usual care, implementation of the CDR in the evaluation of pediatric patients with BAT would reduce health care costs and abdominal CT imaging with a slight increase in risk of missed IAI. Does Increased CT Scan Usage Improve Mortality for Patients with Blunt Trauma? Ameer F. Ibrahim, Juliana Wilson, Grace Sousa, Ronald Moscati, and Michael Manka The State University of New York at Buffalo, Buffalo, NY Background: Use of CT scans to evaluate patients with blunt trauma has surged. Though supportive data are minimal, routine head-through-pelvis CTs are thought to reduce morbidity and mortality. However, CT scans are not without cost and potential adverse effects. There have been no studies to evaluate whether increased number of CT scans result in improved mortality in trauma patients.

TABREF521.text: table shows the deaths among subjects stratified by number of scans received. In the logistic regression model, age (OR = 1.03, 95% CI 1.02-1.05) and ISS (OR = 1.13, 95% CI 1.11-1.15) were significant independent predictors of mortality. After controlling for age and ISS, the number of CT scans (OR = 0.85, 95% CI 0.69-1.04) was not a significant independent predictor of mortality. all AAL measurements. Descriptive statistics were used to analyze the data.Results: 84% were male. Average injury severity scale was 17.7 (range 1.0 -66.0). Average BMI was 26.8 (range 16.5 -48.4). Failure rate was defined as CW ! 80 mm. Safety rate was determined as VS > 80 mm. Average CWT and VS, failure rate and safety rate, and AOE at MCL, AAL-close, and AAL-perpendicular are shown in the table. Conclusion: Eight cm catheters have a significantly lower failure rate based on CWT at all locations compared to 5 cm catheters. Eight cm catheters have a similar safety profile at all locations except for left AAL when taken from skin to closest vital structure. Increasing angle of entry from horizontal at AAL greatly improves safety rate, especially on the left. Results suggest 8 cm catheters have greater efficacy and similar safety for needle decompression at all sites. The Role of Necroptosis in Burn Injury Progression in a Rat Comb Burn Model Avanish S. Reddy, Ariel Abraham, Steve A. McClain, Steven Sandoval, Richard A F Clark, and Adam J. Singer Stony Brook University, Stony Brook, NY

TABREF522.text: : In the first experiment, nearly all unburned interspaces in both the experimental and control rats underwent necrosis(47/48,  97.9% vs. 48/48, 100%; P=NS). Similarly in the second experiment, there were no differences in the percentage of unburned interspaces undergoing necrosis within seven days of injury in rats treated with two doses of necrostatin-1 or the control vehicle (46/48, 95.8% vs. 48/ 48, 100%; P=NS). There were no obvious systemic adverse reactions or wound infections noted in rats injected with necrostatin-1.Conclusion: Injection of rats with either a single intra-peritoneal dose or two intravenous doses of necrostatin-1 failed to reduce burn injury progression in a rat comb burn model. This may be due to inactivity of necrostatin-1 or the lack of a role of necroptosis in burn injury progression in the rat comb burn model.Background: Substance abuse is a major risk factor for traumatic injury. Level I trauma centers in the United States are currently required to provide screening and brief interventions (SBI) only for alcohol abuse. The Alcohol, Smoking and Substance Involvement Screening Test (ASSIST) project, developed by the World Health Organization, includes a validated screening measure for all substances of abuse.

TABREF523.text: 718AnEstimate of Inaccurate Physician Documentation Using Electronic Medical Records in the Emergency Department Jonathan W. Heidt, Richard Griffey, and Charles Kircher Washington University School of Medicine in Saint Louis, Saint Louis, MO Background: Recently, the Department of Health and HumanServices and others have expressed concerns regarding potential fraudulent or dangerous documentation in electronic medical records (EMRs), particularly in emergency departments (EDs), including upcoding, "chart cloning", and physical exams documented but not performed. Efficiencies achieved by EMRs' use of checkbox items that script text when selected may contribute to documentation error, the prevalence of which is unknown. Intentional inaccurate documentation is a provocative charge that is complicated to demonstrate, while documentation error would seem far more common.

TABREF524.text: : Among 1044 visits documenting RE and 1366 documenting PE, 796 were eliminated by chief complaint or diagnosis for RE and 1254 for PE. Approximately 2.5 % (95% CI 1.8%-3.5%) of documented PEs and 8.1% (6.6%-9.9%) of documented REs did not have clear indications in the medical record. Inter-rater reliability was strong (k = 1.0 for PE and 0.75 for RE). Conclusion: We found 2.5% of pelvic exams and 8.1% of rectal exams were documented in the absence of evidence supporting an indication. Documentation of these items did not affect E/M level assigned. Documentation error may be a function of checkbox interfaces. Patient Perceptions of Electronic Medical Record Data Entry Methods Brian Cory 1 , Annette O. Arthur 1 , Alicia Krummel 2 , Peyton Holder 1 , Christopher Tainter 1 , and Stephen H. Thomas 1 University of Oklahoma, Tulsa, OK; 2 University of Oklahoma College of Medicine, Oklahoma City, OK Background: The electronic medical record (EMR) has become standard in most EDs, but there is little data assessing patient perceptions of EMR data entry methods. Objectives: The aim of this study is to assess the perceptions of patients, families, and visitors on the effect of bedside EMR data entry on the patient-doctor interaction. Methods: Design: This prospective survey study was conducted in an urban academic ED with an approximate annual census of 50,000. Research assistants queried a convenience sample of 100 patients about their level of agreement on a five-point Likert scale on the following statements: Q1: Having the doctor take notes while I talk increases accuracy of the doctor's record. Q2: Having the doctor typing while I'm talking is distracting. Q3: If the doctor is going to take notes while I talk, use of computer note entry will increase accuracy compared to handwriting. Q4: If the doctor is going to take computer notes while I talk, it's better to do so on a tablet computer while facing me, as compared to typing on a keyboard facing a computer screen. Analysis: Tabulation of results was primarily descriptive, with use of STATA 12MP to calculate binomial exact 95% CIs; lack of overlap of 95% CIs was taken to indicate significantly different proportions. Results: A majority of patients agreed with Q1 (83%, 95% CI 74-90%). A minority agreed with Q2 (20%, 95% CI 3-29%). For Q3 and Q4, roughly half of patients (for each query, 53% with 95% CI 43-63%) were "neutral." For Q3, of the 47% who expressed a preference, 36% (95% CI, 23-51%) disagreed and 64% (95% CI, 49-77%) agreed. For Q4, of the 47% who expressed a preference, 17% (95% CI, 8-31%) disagreed and 83% (95% CI, 69-92%) agreed.

TABREF525.text: 720AnEHR-Integrated Mobile App Quantitatively Improves Emergency Medicine Resident NIH Stroke Scale Documentation James R. Foster II, Jonathan A. Edlow, Jonathan Fisher, Steven Horng, and Larry A. Nathanson Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, and Harvard Medical School, Boston, MA Background: The NIH stroke scale (NIHSS) is an important tool to aid in decision making for patients who present to the ED with suspected acute ischemic stroke. Previous studies indicate that the documentation of NIHSS by emergency physicians is poor. We sought to improve the documentation rate by streamlining NIHSS documentation into clinical workflow. We developed a mobile device application that is integrated into our ED electronic health record (EHR).Objectives: To determine whether a mobile NIHSS application can quantitatively improve emergency medicine resident documentation of the NIHSS elements in the medical record.

TABREF526.text: A mobile, EHR-integrated NIHSS app improves both the rate and quantity of NIHSS documentation. Further studies are needed to determine whether improvements in documentation translate to improvements in clinical care. Effect of a Computerized Decision Support System on Time to Antibiotic Initiation for Severe Sepsis Brandan Crum, Jeffrey Green, Jasmine Nettiksimmons, Arica Nesper, Ayan Patel, Hien Nguyen, Timothy Albertson, and Edward Panacek University of California Davis Medical Center, Sacramento, CA Background: Delay in antimicrobial administration for adults with severe sepsis may be associated with increased risk of mortality. Computerized decision support systems (CDSS) may speed recognition of severe sepsis and prompt initiation of therapy. Objectives: To determine whether implementation of a sepsis screening CDSS decreased time to antibiotic initiation for adults with severe sepsis.Methods: This single center, retrospective, pre/post analysis was conducted at an academic Level I trauma center that introduced a sepsis CDSS on 7/13/2011. Study time-periods (pre-alert: 11/1/10-6/30/11; postalert: 11/1/11-6/30/12) were selected a priori as the longest consecutive, seasonally similar dates without significant changes to ED staffing or infrastructure. Criteria for study inclusion were: age ! 18 years old; no ED visit within the 12 months prior to study periods; sepsis alert criteria ( ! 2 SIRS criteria documented within 120 minutes); infectious ED diagnosis OR symptom diagnosis and antibiotic administration in the ED; and acute organ dysfunction (lactate ! 4.0 mmol/L, persistent hypotension within 6 hours of triage or vasopressor use) in the ED. ED vital signs (within 6 hours of triage) were queried with an automated algorithm for all adult ED visits during study time-periods.The primary outcome was time from ED triage to first antibiotic. Change between the study periods was estimated with a Cox proportional hazards model which controlled for demographics, illness severity [Rapid Emergency Medicine Score (REMS)], ED crowding, and clustering by physician. Results: 18,000+ patient records were queried with 200 ED patients meeting inclusion criteria (98 pre, 102 post). Patients in each group had similar demographics (age, sex, insurance status), but post-alert patients had higher REMS scores (p<0.001), and the post-alert period had longer ED admission hold times (p=0.001). Median time to first antibiotic was shorter in the post-alert period (post-alert vs. pre-alert: 1.8 hours vs. 2.3 hours, p-value 0.004), but after adjustment, the difference was not significant (hazard ratio post-alert vs. pre-alert: 1.27, 95%CI 0.93, 1.73). Conclusion: The CDSS sepsis alert was associated with a nonsignificant but suggestive decrease in time to antibiotic administration in adults with severe sepsis seen in the ED. 722 A Soluble Guanylate Cyclase Stimulator, Bay 41-8543, Preserves Pulmonary Artery Endothelial Function in Experimental Pulmonary Embolism John A. Watts 1 , Michael A. Gellar 1 , Mary-Beth K. Fulkerson 1 , and Jeffrey A. Kline 2 Background: Pulmonary embolism (PE) causes pulmonary hypertension by vascular obstruction and altered active tone in nonoccluded vessels. Our recent studies show that BAY 41-8543 reduces pulmonary vascular resistance in experimental PE. Objectives: To test if treatment of rats with BAY 41-8543 protects against pulmonary artery vascular endothelial dysfunction in acute experimental PE. Methods: Moderate 5 hr. experimental PE was induced in anesthetized, male Sprague-Dawley rats by infusing 25 um polystyrene microspheres (2 million/100 gram body wt) in the right jugular vein. Rats were treated with BAY 41 IV)  or its solvent at the induction of PE. Control rats received vehicle for microspheres. Ring segments (1-2 mm wide), isolated from primary pulmonary artery branches, were bathed in oxygenated Krebs buffer (37 o C). Resting tension was set (2 grams), rings were contracted with phenylephrine (10 -6 M), and endothelium-dependent dilation was tested with acetylcholine (10 -7 M -10 -5 M). Endothelium-independent dilation was tested with nitroglycerin (10 -5 M), or BAY 41-8543 (10 -8 M -10 -6 M). Doseresponse tests were by repeated measures ANOVA (n = 6-8/group). Oxidant stress was assessed as increased 4-hydroxynoneal (4-HNE) immunohistochemistry in pulmonary arteries or malondialdehyde (MDA) in plasma (n = 9-15/group) (TBARS kit, Cayman Chemical), tested by ANOVA. Significance = p < 0.05 Results: PE significantly decreased endothelium-dependent dilation compared with control rings (dose x group interaction p < 0.001), while endothelium-independent dilation was unchanged. Endotheliumdependent dilation significantly improved in PE + BAY 41-8543 compared with PE (dose x group interaction p = 0.04). PE also caused increased 4-HNE immunohistochemistry in pulmonary arteries and a 2.2-fold increase in plasma MDA (p < 0.009, PE vs. control). Treatment of PE animals with BAY 41-8543 significantly reduced 4-HNE in arteries and MDA in plasma (p = 0.04 PE + BAY41-8543 vs. PE) to levels not significantly different from control. Conclusion: Experimental PE produced significant pulmonary artery endothelial dysfunction, which was associated with oxidant stress (lipid peroxidation). Treatment of animals with the soluble guanylate cyclase stimulator BAY 41-8543 lowered oxidant stress and preserved endothelial function. Co-targeting of Thrombomodulin and EPCR to the Pulmonary Endothelium is Protective in a Mouse Model of Sepsisinduced Acute Lung Injury Colin F. Greineder, Blaine Zern, Ann-Marie Chacko, Ronald Carnemolla, Sergei Zaytsev, and Vladimir R. Muzykantov University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA
